Bibliographic details for the Source Text Henry Chettle, d. 1607? / Anthony Munday, 1553-1633 (1560?-1607? / 1560- 1633) The Death Of Robert, Earle Of Hvntington. Otherwise Called Robin Hood of merrie Sherwodde: with the lamentable Tragedie of chaste Matilda, his faire maid Marian, poysoned at Dunmowe by King Iohn. Acted by the Right Honourable, the Earle of Notingham, Lord high Admirall of England, his seruants London Imprinted ... for William Leake 1601 [91] p. Preliminaries omitted.
Play details
The death of Robert, Earle of Huntington. Genre: History. Date first published: 1601. Date first performed: 1598 ?

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Earl of Huntington/Robin Hood Maid Marion/Matilda Lord Chester Sir John Eltam Bishop of Ely Skelton Earl of Leicester Richmond Prior of York Little John Jinny Lord Salisbury Much/Clown Scarlet Lord Lacy/Lord Fitzwater Prince John Queen Elinor King Richard Justice Warman Friar Tuck Warmans Wife Servant Messenger Combined speech Scathlock Sir Doncaster Sir Hugh Lacy within Song/Chorus/Epilogue Bonville Aubery de Vere/Oxford Hubert Mowbray Young Bruse Old Bruse Lady Bruse Brand Abbess Monk Sir William Blunt Queen Isabell

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.p: Holla, holla, holla: follow, follow, follow.

Now benedicite, what foul absurdity, folly and foolery had like to followed me! I and my mates, like addle pates, inviting great States, to see our last play, are hunting the hay, with ho, that way, the goodly Hart ran, with follow little Iohn, Much play the man; and I, like a sot, have wholly forgot the course of our plot: but crossbow lie down, come on Friars gown, hood cover my crown, and with a low beck, prevent a sharpe check.
sp.l: Blithe sit ye all, and wink at our rude cry,
Mind where we left, in Sheerewod merrily,
The king, his train, Robin, his yeomen tall
Gone to the wood to see the fat deer fall:
We left maid Marian busy in the bower,
And pretty Iinny looking, every hour,
For their returning from the hunting game,
And therefore seek to set each thing in frame.
Warman all woeful for his sin we left.
Sir Doncaster, whose villainies and theft,
You never heard of, but too soon ye shall,
Hurt with the Prior; shame them both befall,
[25] They two will make our mirth be short and small.
But lest I bring ye sorrow ere the time,
Pardon I beg of your well judging eyen,
And take in part bad prologue, and rude play:
The hunters holloo, Tucke must needs away.
sp.p: Therefore down weed, bow do the deed, to make the Stag bleed, and if my hand speed, hey for a cry, with a throat strained hie, and a loud yell, at the beasts fall.

div.stage: Exit. Holloo within. Enter King, Ely, Fitzwater, Salsbury, Chester, Prince Iohn, little Iohn, Scathlocke.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Where is our mother?

sp.speaker: Pr. Iohn.
sp.l: Mounted in a stand.
Sir fallow deer have died by her hand.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Three Stags I slew.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Two Bucks by me fell down.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: As many died by me.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: But I had three.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Scathlocke, where is Much?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: When last I saw him, may it please your Grace,
He and the Friar footed it apace.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Scathlocke, no Grace, your fellow and plain Iohn.

sp.speaker: Lit. Ioh.
sp.l: I warrant you, Much will be here anon.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Thinkst thou little Iohn, that he must Iinny wed?

sp.speaker: Lit. Ioh.
sp.l: No doubt he must.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Then to adorn hie head, we shall have horns good store.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: God, for thy grace,
How could I miss the Stag I had in chase!
Twice did I hit him in the very neck,
When back my arrows flew, as they had smit
On some sure armour. Where is Robin Hood,
And the wight Scarlet? Seek them little Iohn.
I will have that Stag before I dine today.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: O the friar, the friar, the friar.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why, how now Much?

sp.p: Cry ye mercy, master king. Marry this is the matter; Scarlet is following the Stag you hit, and has almost lodged him: now the Friar has the best bow, but yours, in all the field: which and Scarlet had, he would have him straight.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Where is thy master?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: Nay, I cannot tell, nor the Friar neither.

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: I hear them holloo, far off in the wood.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come Much, canst lead us where as Scarlet is?

sp.speaker: Muc.
sp.l: Never fear you; follow me.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: You were resolved to have him poisoned,
Or killed, or made away, you cared not how.
What devil makes you doubtful now to do it?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Why Doncaster? his kindness in our needs.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: A plague upon his kindness, let him die.
I never tempered poison in my life, but I employed it.
By the mass and I lose this,
For ever look to lose my company.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: But will you give it him?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: That cannot be.
The Queen, Earl Chester, and Earl Salsbury,
If they once see me, I am a dead man:
Or did they hear my name, I will lay my life,
They all would hunt me, for my life.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: What hast thou done to them?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Faith, some odd toys,
That made me fly the south: but pass we them:
Here is the poison: will you give it Robin?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Now by this gold I will.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Or as I said, for ever I defy your company.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Well, he shall die, and in his jollity:
And in my head I have a policy
To make him die disgraced.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: O tell it Prior.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: [25] I will, but not as now:
We will seek a place, the woods have many ears,
And some methinks are calling for the Friar.

div.head: SCEANE. III.
div.stage: Enter, calling the Frier, as afore.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: The Friar, the Friar?

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: Why, where is this Friar?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Here sir. what is your desire?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why Friar, what a murrain dost thou mean?
The King calls for thee. For, a mighty stag,
(That hath a copper ring about his neck,
With letters on it, which he would have read)
Hath Scarlet killed. I pray thee go thy way.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Master I will, no longer will I stay.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Good uncle be more careful of your health,
And you sir Doncaster, your wounds are green.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Through your great kindness, we are comforted.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And Warman, I advise you to more mirth.
Shun solitary walks, keep company,
Forget your fault: I have forgiven the fault.
Good Warman be more blithe, and at this time,
A little help my Marian and her maid:
Much shall come to you straight: a little now,
We must all strive to do the best we may.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: On you and her I will wait, until my dying day.

div.stage: Exeunt, and as they are going out, Doncaster puls Warman.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Warman a word. My good Lord Prior and I
Are full of grief, to see thy misery.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: My misery, sir Doncaster? why? I thank God,
I never was in better state than now.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: [25] Why, what a servile slavish mind hast thou?
Art thou a man, and canst be such a beast,
Ass-like to bear the burthen of thy wrong?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What wrong have I? Is it wrong to be relieved?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Relieved sayst thou?
Why, shallow witted fool,
Dost thou not see Robins ambitious pride?
And how he climbs by pitying, and aspires,
By humble looks, good deeds, and such fond toys,
To be a monarch, reigning over us,
As if we were the vassals to his will?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I am his vassal, and I will be still.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Warman, thou art a fool. I do confess,
Were these good deeds done in sincerity,
Pity of mind, thine or this knights distress,
Without vain brags, it were true charity:
But to relieve our fainting bodies wants,
And grieve our souls with quips, and bitter braids,
Is good turns overturned: no thanks we owe
To any, whatsoever helps us so.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Neither himself, nor any that he keeps,
Ever upbraided me, since I came last.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: O God have mercy on thee, silly ass.
Doth he not say to every guest that comes;
This same is Warman, that was once my steward?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And what of that?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Is it not as much to say;
Why, here he stands that once did me betray.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Did he not bring a troop to grace himself,
Like Captives waiting on a conquerors chair,
And calling of them out, by one and one,
Presented them, like fairings, to the king?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: O, Aye: there was a rare invention:
A plague upon the fool.
I hate him worse for that than all the rest.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Why should you hate him? why should you or you
Envy this noble Lord, thus as you do?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Nay rather, why dost thou not join in hate
With us, that lately livedest like us, in wealthy state?
Remember this, remember foolish man,
How thou hast been the Shrieve of Notingham.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Cry to thy thoughts, let this thought never cease,
I have been Justice of my Sovereigns peace,
Lord of fair livings: men with cap and knee,
In liveries waited hourly on me.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: And when thou thinkst, thou hast been such and such,
Think then what it is to be a mate to Much,
To run when Robin bids, come at his call,
Be mistress Marians man.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Nay think withal

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: [75] What shall I think? but think upon my need,
When men fed dogs, and me they would not feed:
When I despaired through want, and sought to die,
My piteous master, of his charity,
Forgave my fault, relieved and saved me:
This do I think upon, and you should think
(If you had hope of souls salvation)
First Prior, that he is of thy flesh and blood,
That thou art uncle unto Robin Hood:
That by extortion thou didst get his lands:
God, and I know how it came to thy hands:
How thou pursuedest him in his misery,
And how heaven plagued thy hearts extremity:
Think Doncaster, when, hired by this Prior,
Thou camest to take my master with the Friar,
And wert thyself taken, how he set thee free,
Gave thee an hundred pound to comfort thee,
And both bethink ye how but yesterday,
Wounded and naked in the field you lay,
How with his own hand he did raise your heads,
Poured balm into your wounds, your bodies fed,
Watched when ye slept, wept when he saw your woe,

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Stay Warman, stay: I grant that he did so,
And you, turned honest, have forsworn the villain?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Even from my soul, I villainy defy.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: [100] A blessed hour: a fit time now to die:

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: And you shall, Conscience.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O forgive me, God,
And save my master from their bloody hands.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: What, hast thou made him sure?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: It is dead sure: he is dead, if that be sure.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Then let us thrust the dagger in his hand,
And when the next comes, cry he killed himself.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: That must be now: yonder comes Robin Hood.
No life in him.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: No, no, not any life.
Three mortal wounds have let in piercing air,
And at their gaps, his life is clean let out.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Who is it uncle that you so bemoan?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Warman, good nephew, whom sir Doncaster and I
Found freshly bleeding, as he now doth lie.
You were scarce gone, when he did stab himself.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: O God, he in his own hand holds his own hearts hurt,
I dreaded too much his distressed look:
Belike the wretch despaired, and slew himself.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Nay, that is most sure, yet he had little reason,
Considering how well you used him.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Well, I am sorry; but must not be sad,
Because the King is coming to my bower.
Help me, I pray thee, to remove his body,
Lest he should come and see him murdered.
Sometime anon he shall be buried.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Good, all is good: this is as I desire.
Now for a face of pure hypocrisy:
Sweet murder, clothe thee in religious weeds,
Reign in my bosom, that with help of thee,
I may effect this Robins Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Nay, nay, you must not take this thing so heavily.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: A bodies loss, sir Doncaster, is much:
But a souls too, is more to be bemoaned.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Truly I wonder at your virtuous mind:
O God to one so kind, who would be unkind!
Let go this grief, now must you put on joy,
And for the many favours I have found,
So much exceeding all conceit of mine,
Unto your cheer, I will add a precious drink,
Of colour rich, and red, sent me from Rome.
There is in it Moly, Syrian Balsamum,
Golds rich Elixir: O it is precious!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Where is it uncle?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: As yesterday,
Sir Doncaster and I rid on our way,
Thieves did beset us, bound us as you saw:
And among other things, did take from me,
This rich confection: but regardlessly,
As common drink, they cast, into a bush,
The bottle, which this day sir Doncaster
Fetched, and hath left it in the inner lodging:
I tell you cousin (I do love you well)
A pint of this ransomed the Sophies son,
When he was taken in Natolia.
I meant indeed to give it my liege Lord,
In hope to have his favour: but to you
I put myself, be my good friend,
And, in your own restoring, me restore.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Uncle I will, you need urge that no more.
But what is the vertues of this precious drink?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: It keeps fresh youth, restores diseased sight,
Helps natures weakness, smoothes the scars of wounds,
And cools the entrails with a balmy breath,
When they by thirst or travel boyle with heat.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Uncle I thank you, pray you let me have
A cup prepared, against the king comes in,
To cool his heat: myself will give it him.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: And when he drinks, be bold to say he drinks
A richer draught than that dissolved pearl,
Which Cleopatra drank to Antonie.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I have much business; let it be your charge,
To make this rich draught ready for the King,
And I will quit it, pray ye do not fail.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: I warrant you, good Nephew.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Better, and better still.
We thought before but to have poisoned him,
And now shall Robin Hood destroy the king.
Even when the King, the Queen the Prince, the Lords
Joy in his vertues, this supposed vice
Will turn, to sharpe hate, their exceeding love.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, I cannot choose but laugh,
To see my cousin cozened in this sort.
Fail him quoth you? nay hang me if I do.
But Doncaster art sure the poisons are well mixed?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Tut, tut, let me alone for poisoning:
I have already turned over four, or five,
That angered me. But tell me Prior,
Wherefore so deadly dost thou hate thy cousin?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Shall I be plain? Because if he were dead,
I should be made the Earl of Huntington.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: A pretty cause: But thou a church-man art.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Tut man, if that would fall,
I will have a dispensation, and turn temporal.
But tell me Doncaster, why dost thou hate him?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: By the Mass, I cannot tell. O yes, now I have it.
I hate thy cousin, Earl of Huntington,
Because so many love him as there do,
And I myself am loved of so few.
Nay, I have other reasons for my hate;
He is a fool, and will be reconciled,
To any foe he hath: he is too mild,
Too honest for this world, fitter for heaven:
He will not kill these greedy cormorants,
Nor strip base peasants of the wealth they have:
He does abuse a thieves name and an outlaws,
And is indeed no outlaw, nor no thief,
He is unworthy of such reverent names.
Besides, he keeps a paltry whinling girl,
And will not bed, forsooth, before he bride:
I will stand to it, he abuses maidenhead,
That will not take it, being offered:
Hinders the common wealth of able men.
Another thing I hate him for again:
He says his prayers, fasts eves, gives alms, does good:
For these and such like crimes, swears Doncaster
To work the speedy death of Robin Hood.

sp.speaker: Pri,
sp.l: Well said i'faith. Hark, hark, the king returns:
To do this deed, my heart like fuel burns.

div.head: SCEANE. IIII.
div.stage: Winde hornes. Enter King, Queene, Iohn, Fitzwater, Ely, Chester, Salsbury, Lester, little Iohn, Frier Tuck, Scarlet, Scathlocke, and Much, Frier Tuck carrying a Stags head, dauncing.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Gramercy Friar for thy glee,
Thou greatly hast contented me,
What with thy sporting and thy game,
I swear I highly pleased am.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: It was my masters whole desire
That maiden, yeoman, swain and friar
Their arts and wits should all apply,
For pleasure of your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Son Richard, look I pray you on the ring,
That was about the neck of the last stag.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Was his name Scarlet, that shot off his neck?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Chester, it was this honest fellow Scarlet:
This is the fellow, and a yeoman bold,
As ever coursed the swift Hart on the mould.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Friar, here is somewhat graved upon the Ring,
I pray thee read it. Mean while list to me;
This while, most compassing the Friar about the Ring.
Scarlet and Scathlock, you bold brethren,
Twelve pence a day I give each for his fee,
And henceforth see ye live like honest men.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We will my Liege, else let us die the death.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: A boon, a boon, upon my knee,
Good king Richard, I beg of thee.
sp.p: For indeed sir, the troth is, Much is my father, and he [25] is one of your tenants in Kings Mill at Wakefield all on a green: O there dwelleth a jolly pinder, at Wakefield all on a green: Now I would have you, if you will do so much for me, to set me forward in the way of marriage to Iinny: the mill would not be cast away upon us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Much, be thou ever master of that mill,
I give it thee for thine inheritance.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: Thanks precious Prince of courtesy.
I will to Inny, and tell her of my lands i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Here Friar, here, here it begins,
When Harold hare-foot reigned king,
About my neck he put this ring.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: In Harolds time, more than a hundred year,
Hath this ring been about this new slain Deer!
I am sorry now it died: but let the same
Head, ring and all be sent to Notingham,
And in the Castle kept for monuments.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: My Liege, I heard an old tale long ago,
That Harold being Goodwins son of Kent,
When he had got fair Englands government,
Hunted for pleasure once within this wood,
And singled out a fair and stately Stag,
Which foot to foot, the king in running caught:
And sure this was the Stag.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It was no doubt.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: But some my Lord affirm,
That Iulius Cæsar many years before,
Took such a Stag, and such a Poesy writ.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It should not be in Iulius Cæsars time:
There was no English used in this Land,
Until the Saxons came, and this is writ
In Saxon characters.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Well, it was a goodly beast.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now earl Robert?

sp.speaker: Fri,
sp.l: A forfeit, a forfeit, my liege Lord.
My masters laws are on record,
The Court-roll here your Grace may see.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I pray thee Friar, read them me.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: One shall suffice, and this is he.
No man that cometh in this wood,
To feast, or dwell with Robin Hood ,
Shall call him Earl, Lord, Knight, or Squire,
He no such titles doth desire,
But Robin Hood, plain Robin Hood,
That honest yeoman stout and good,
On pain of forfeiting a mark,
That must be paid to me his Clarke,
My liege, my liege, this law you broke,
Almost in the last word you spoke.
[75] That crime may not acquitted be,
Till Friar Tuck receive his fee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: There is more than twenty marks, mad Friar.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: If thus you pay the Clarke his hire,
Oft may you forfeit, I desire.
You are a perfect penitent,
And well you do your wrong repent:
For this your Highness liberal gift,
I here absolve you without shrift.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Gramercies Friar. Now Robin Hood ,
Sith Robin Hood it needs must be,
I was about to ask before,
If thou didst see the great Stags fall.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I did my Lord, I saw it all.
But missing this same prating Friar,
And hearing you so much desire
To have the lozels company,
I went to seek Small honesty.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: But you found much, when you found me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Aye, Much my man: but not a jot
Of honesty in thee, God wot.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Robin, you do abuse the Friar.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Madam, I dare not call him liar,
He may be bold with me, he knows.
How now Prince Iohn, how goes, how goes
[100] This wood-man's life with you today?
My fellow Wodnet you would be.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I am thy fellow, thou dost see:
And to be plain, as God me save,
So well I like thee, merry knave,
That I thy company must have:
Nay, and I will.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Nay, and you shall.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: My Lord, you need not fear at all,
But you shall have his company,
He will be bold I warrant you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Know you where ever a spring is nigh?
Fain would I drink, I am right dry.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I have a drink within my bower,
Of pleasing taste, and sovereign power:
My reverend uncle gives it me,
To give unto your Majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I would be loath indeed, being in heat,
To drink cold water. Let us to thy bower.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Run Friar before, and bid my uncle be in readiness.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Gon with a trice, on such good business.

div.head: SCEANE. V.
div.stage: Enter Marian, with a white apron.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What Much? What Iinny Much? I say.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: What is the matter mistress?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I pray thee see, the fueller
Suffer the cook to want no wood.
Good Lord, where is this idle girl?
Why Iinny?
I come forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I pray thee bring the flowers forth.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I will go send her mistress, and help the cooks, if they have any need.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Dispatch good Much. What Iin I say?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: Hie ye, hie ye: she calls for life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Indeed, indeed, you do me wrong,
To let me cry, and call so long.

sp.speaker: Iin.
sp.l: Forsooth, I strawed the dining bowers.
And smoothed the walks with herbs and flowers,
The yeoman's tables I have spread,
Dressed salts, laid trenchers, set on bread:
Nay all is well, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are not well I promise you,
Your foresleeves are not pinned (fie, fie)
And all your head-gear stands awry.
Give me the flowers: Go in for shame,
And quickly see you mend the same.

div.stage: Exit Iinny. Marian strewing flowers. Enter sir Doncaster, Prior.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: How busy mistress Marian is?
She thinks this is her day of bliss.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: But it shall be the woefullest day
That ever chanced her, if I may.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why are you two thus in the air?
Your wounds are green,
Good cuz have care.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thanks for your kindness, gentle maid.
My cousin Robert us hath prayed,
To help him in this business.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Sir Doncaster, sir Doncaster?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Holla.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: I pray you, did you see the Prior?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Why, here I am. What wouldst thou Friar.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: The king is heated in the chase,
And posteth hitherward apace.
He told my master he was dry,
And he desires ye, presently
To send the drink whereof ye spake.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Come, it is here; haste let us make

div.stage: Exeunt Prior, and Frier. Enter King, Iohn, Queene, Scarlet, Scathlocke, Ely, Fitzwater, Salsbury, Chester. Marian kneeles downe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Most gracious Sovereign, welcome once again:
Welcome to you, and all your princely train.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thanks lovely hostess: we are homely guests.
Where is Robin Hood? He promised me some drink.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your handmaid. Robin will not then be long.
The Friar indeed came running to his uncle,
Who with sir Doncaster were here with me,
And altogether went for such a drink.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Well, in a better time it could not come,
For I am very hot and passing dry.

div.stage: Enter Robin Hoode, a cuppe, a towell, leading Doncaster: Tuck, and Much pulling the Prior.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Traitor, I will draw thee out before the king.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Come murderous Prior.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: Come ye dogs face.

sp.speaker: Ki
sp.l: Why how now Robin? where is the drink you bring?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Lay hold on these.
Far be it, I should bring your Majesty,
The drink these two prepared for your taste.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why Robin Hood, be brief and answer me:
I am amazed at thy troubled looks.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Long will not my ill looks amaze your Grace.
I shortly look, never to look again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Never to look? What will it still be night?
If thou look never, day can never be.
What ails my Robin? Wherefore dost thou faint?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Because I cannot stand: yet now I can.
Thanks to my king, and thanks to Marian.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Robin be brief, and tell us what hath chanced?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I must be brief, for I am sure of death,
Before a long tale can be half way told.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Of death, my son? bright sun of all my joy?
Death cannot have the power of virtuous life.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Not of the vertues, but the life it can.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What dost thou speak of death? how shouldst thou die?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: By poison, and the Priors treachery.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Why, take this sovereign powder at my hands,
Take it and live in spite of poisons power.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Aye, set him forward. Powders quoth ye? ha,
I am a fool then, if a little dust,
The shaving of a horn, a Bezars stone,
Or any Antidote have power to stay
The execution of my hearts resolve.
Tut, tut, you labour lovely Queen, in vain,
And on a thankless groom your toil bestow.
Now hath your foe revenged you of your foe:
Robin shall die, if all the world said no.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How the Wolf howls! Fly like a tender Kid
Into thy shepherds bosom. Shield me love.
Canst thou not Robin? Where shall I be hid?
O God, these Ravens will seize upon thy Dove.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: They cannot hurt thee, pray thee do not fear,
Base curs will couch, the Lion being near.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How works my powder?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Very well, fair Queen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dost thou feele any ease?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I shall, I trust, anon:
Sleep falls upon mine eyes.
O I must sleep, and they that love me, do not waken me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sleep in my lap, and I will sing to thee.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: He should not sleep.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I must, for I must die:
While I live therefore let me have some rest.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Aye, let him rest, the poison urges sleep.
When he awakes, there is no hope of life.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Of life? now by the little time I have to live,
He cannot live one hour for your lives.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Villain what art thou?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Why, I am a knight.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Thou wert indeed.
If it so please your Grace,
I will describe my knowledge of this wretch.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Do Chester.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: This Doncaster, for so the felon hight,
Was, by the king your father, made a knight,
And well in arms he did himself behave.
Many a bitter storm, the wind of rage
Blasted this Realm with, in those woeful days,
When the unnatural fights continued,
Between your kingly father and his sons.
This cut-throat, knighted in that time of woe,
Seized on a beauteous Nun, at Barkhamsted,
As we were marching toward Winchester,
After proud Lincolne was compelled to yield,
He took this virgin straying in the field:
For all the Nuns and every Convent fled
The dangers that attended on our troops.
For those sad times too oft did testify,
Wars rage hath no regard of piety.
She humbly prayed him, for the love of heaven,
To guide her to her fathers, two miles thence.
He swore he would, and very well he might:
For to the camp he was a Forager.
Upon the way they came into a wood,
Wherein, in brief, he stripped this tender maid:
Whose lust, when she in vain had long withstood,
Being by strength and torments overlaid,
He did a sacrilegious deed of rape,
And left her bathed in her own tears and blood.
When she revived, she to her fathers got,
And got her father to make just complaint,
Unto your mother, being then in camp.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Is this the villain Chester, that defiled
Sir Eustace Stutuiles chaste and beauteous child?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: I Madam, this is he,
That made a wench dance naked in a wood:
And for she did deny what I desired,
I scourged her for her pride, till her fair skin
With stripes was checkered like a vintners grate.
And what was this? A mighty matter sure.
I have a thousand more than she defiled,
And cut the squeaking throats of some of them:
I grieve I did not hers,

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Punish him Richard.
A fairer virgin never saw the sun ---
A chaster maid was never sworn a Nun.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How scaped the villain punishment, that time?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I rent his spurs off, and disgraded him.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: And then he railed upon the Queen and me.
Being committed, he his keeper slew,
And to your father fled, who pardoned him.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: God give his soul a pardon for that sin.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: O had I heard his name, or seen his face,
I had defended Robin from this chance.
Ah, villain shut those gloomy lights of thine.
Rememberest thou a little son of mine,
Whose nurse at Wilton first thou ravishedest,
And slewest two maids that did attend on them?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: I grant, I dashed the brains out of a brat,
Thine if he were, I care not: had he been
The first born comfort of a royal king,
And should have yielded when Doncaster cried peace,
I would have done by him as then I did.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Soon shall the world be rid of such a wretch,
Let him be hanged alive, in the high way, that joineth to the power.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Alive or dead, I reck not how I die.
You, them, and these, I desperately defy.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Repent, or never look to be absolved,
But die accursed as thou deservest well.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Then give me my desert; curse one by one.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: First I accurse thee, and, if thou persist,
Unto damnation leave thee wretched man.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: What do I care for your damnation?
Am I not doomed to death? what more damnation
Can there ensue your loud and yelling cries?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Yes devil: hear thy fellow spirit speak,
Who would repent; O fain he would repent.
After this bodies bitter punishment,
There is an ever-during endless woe,
A quenchless fire, an unconsuming pain,
Which desperate souls and bodies must endure.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Can you preach this, yet set me on sir Prior,
To run into this endless, quenchless fire?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: High heavens show mercy to my many ills.
Never had this been done, but like a fiend,
Thou temptedest me with ceaseless devilish thoughts.
Therefore I curse, with bitterness of soul,
The hour wherein I saw thy baleful eyes.
My eyes I curse, for looking on those eyes.
My ears I curse, for harkening to thy tongue.
I curse thy tongue for tempting of mine ears.
Each part I curse, that we call thine or mine:
Thine forenticing mine, mine following thine.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: A holy prayer. what Collect have we next?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: My Marian wanteth words, such is her woe:
But old Fitzwater for his girl and him
Begs nothing, but worlds plague for such a foe,
Which causeless harmed a virtuous noble man,
A pitier of his griefs, when he felt grief:
Therefore bethink thee of thy hateful deed,
Thou faithless Prior, and thou this ruthless thief.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Will no man curse me, giving so much cause?
Then Doncaster, ourselves ourselves accurse,
And let no good betide to thee or me.
All the yeomen, Friar, Much, Iinny cry;

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Amen, amen: accursed may ye be,
For murdering Robin, flower of courtesy.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O ring not such a peal for Robins death,
Let sweet forgiveness be my passing bell.
Art thou there Marian? then fly forth my breath:
To die within thy arms contents me well.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Keep in, keep in a little while thy soul,
Till I have poured my soul forth at thy feet.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I slept not uncle, I your grief did hear,
Let him forgive your soul that bought it dear:
Your bodies deed, I in my death forgive,
And humbly beg the king that you may live.
Stand to your Clergy uncle, save your life,
And lead a better life than you have done.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: O gentle Nephew, ah my brothers son,
Thou dying glory of old Huntington,
Wishest thou life to such a murderous foe?
I will not live, sith thou must life forgo.
O happy Warman, blessed in thy end,
Now too too late thy truth I do commend.
O Nephew, Nephew, Doncaster and I
Murdered poor Warman, for he did deny
To join with us in this black tragedy.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Alas poor Warman. Friar, little Iohn,
I told ye both where Warmans body lay:
And of his burial I will dispose anon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is there no law, Lord Ely, to convict,
This Prior, that confesseth murders thus?

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: He is a hallowed man, and must be tried,
And punished by the censure of the Church.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: The Church therein doth err: God doth allow
No Canon to preserve a murderers life.
Richard, king Richard, in thy Grandsires days,
A law was made, the Clergy sworn thereto,
That whatsoever Church-man did commit
Treason, or murder, or false felony,
Should like a secular be punished.
Treason we did, for sure we did intend
King Richards poisoning, Sovereign of this land.
Murder we did in working Warmans end,
And my dear Nephews, by this fatal hand.
And theft we did, for we have robbed the king,
The State, the Nobles, Commons, and his men,
Of a true Peer, firm Pillar, liberal Lord.
Fitzwater we have robbed of a kind son,
And Marians love-joys we have quite undone.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Whoppe, what a coil is here with your confession?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: I ask but judgment for my foul transgression.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy own mouth hath condemned thee.
Hence with him.
Hang this man dead, then see him buried:
But let the other hang alive in chains.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Myself will go, my Lord,
And see sharpe Justice done upon these slaves.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O go not hence Prince Iohn: a word or two
Before I die, I fain would say to you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Robin, we see what we are sad to see,
Death like a champion treading down thy life:
Yet in thy end somewhat to comfort thee,
We freely give to thy betrothed wife,
Beauteous and chaste Matilda, all those lands,
Fallen by thy folly, to the Priors hands,
And by his fault now forfeited to me:
Earl Huntington, she shall thy Countess be,
And thy wight yeomen, they shall wend with me,
Against the faithless enemies of Christ.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Bring forth a Bier, and cover it with green;
That on my death-bed I may here sit down.
At Robins burial let no black be seen,
Let no hand give for him a mourning gown:
For in his death, his king hath given him life,
By this large gift, given to his maiden wife.
Chaste maid Matilda, Countess of account,
Chase with thy bright eyes, all these clouds of woe,
From these fair cheeks, I pray thee sweet do so.
Think it is bootless folly, to complain,
For that which never can be had again.
Queen Elianor, you once were Matilds foe:
Prince Iohn, you long sought her unlawful love:
Let dying Robin Hood entreat you both,
To change those passions Madam turn your hate,
To princely love; Prince Iohn, convert your love
To virtuous passions, chaste and moderate.
O that your gracious right hands would enfold,
Matildas right hand, prisoned in my palm,
And swear to do what Robin Hood desires.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I swear I will, I will a mother be,
To fair Matildas life and chastity.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: When Iohn solicits chaste Matildaes ears,
With lawless suits, as he hath often done:
Or offers to the altars of her eyes,
Lascivious Poems, stuffed with vanities,
He craves to see but short and sour days,
His death be like to Robins he desires,
His perjured body prove a poisoned prey,
For cowled Monks, and barefoot begging Friars.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Enough, enough, Fitzwater, take your child:
My dying frost which no suns heat can thaw,
Closes the powers of all my outward parts,
My freezing blood runs back unto my heart,
Where it assists death, which it would resist:
Only my love a little hinders death.
For he beholds her eyes, and cannot smite:
Then go not yet Matilda, stay a while.
Friar, make speed, and list my latest will.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O let me look, for ever in thy eyes,
And lay my warm breath to thy bloodless lips,
If my sight can restrain deaths tyrannies,
Or keep lives breath within thy bosom locked.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Away, away,
Forbear, my love: all this is but delay.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Come maiden daughter, from my maiden son,
And give him leave to do what must be done.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: First I bequeath my soul to all souls saver,
And will my body to be buried,
At Wakefield, underneath the Abbey wall:
And in this order make my funeral;
When I am dead, stretch me upon this Bier,
My beads and Primer shall my pillow be:
On this side lay my bow, my good shafts here,
Upon my breast the cross, and underneath,
My trusty sword, thus fastened in the sheath.
Let Warmans body at my feet be laid,
Poor Warman, that in my defence did die,
For holy dirges, sing me woodman's songs,
As ye to Wakefield walk, with voices shrill:
This for myself: my goods and plate I give
Among my yeomen: them I do bestow,
Upon my Sovereign, Richard. This is all.
My liege farewell, my love farewell, farewell.
Farewell fair Queen, Prince Iohn and noble Lords.
Father Fitzwater heartily adieu,
Adieu my yeomen tall.
Matilda close mine eyes.
Friar farewell, farewell to all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O must my hands with envious death conspire,
To shut the morning gates of my lives light?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: It is a duty, and thy loves desire,
I will help thee girl to close up Robins sight.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Laments are bootless, tears cannot restore
Lost life: Matilda, therefore weep no more.
And since our mirth is turned into moan,
Our merry sport, to tragic funeral,
We will prepare our power for Austria,
After earl Roberts timeless burial.
Fall to your wood-songs therefore yeomen bold,
And deck his hearse with flowers, that loved you dear,
Dispose his goods, as he hath them disposed.
Fitzwater and Matilda, bide you here,
See you the body unto Wakefield borne,
A little we will bear ye company,
But all of us at London point to meet:
Thither Fitzwater, bring earl Robins men:
And Friar, see you come along with them.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Ah my liege Lord, the Friar faints,
And hath no words to make complaints:
But since he must forsake this place,
He will await, and thanks your Grace.

sp.speaker: Song.
sp.l: Weep, weep, ye wood-men wail,
Your hands with sorrow wring:
Your master Robin Hood lies dead,
Therefore sigh as you sing.
Here lies his Primer and his beads,
His bent bow and his arrows keen,
His good sword and his holy cross,
Now cast on flowers fresh and green:
And as they fall, shed tears and say,
Wella, wella day, wella, wella day:
Thus cast ye flowers and sing,
And on to Wakefield take your way.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Here doth the Friar leave with grievance:
Robin is dead, that graced his entrance:
And being dead he craves his audience,
With this short play, they would have patience.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Nay Fryer, at request of thy kind friend,
Let not thy Play so soon be at an end.
Though Robin Hood be dead, his yeomen gone,
And that thou thinkst there now remains not one,
To act an other Sceane or two for thee:
Yet know full well, to please this company,
We mean to end Matildaes Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Off then, I wish you, with your Kendall green:
Let not sad grief, in fresh array be seen.
Matildaes story is replete with tears,
Wrongs, desolations, ruins, deadly fears.
In, and attire ye: though I tired be,
Yet will I tell my mistress Tragedy.
Apolloes master done I invocate:
To whom henceforth my deeds I dedicate:
That of his Godhead, above all Gods divine,
With his rich spirit he would lighten mine:
That I may sing true lays of trothless deeds,
Which to conceive, my heart through sorrow bleeds.
Cheer thee, sad soul, and in a lofty line,
Thunder out wrong, compassed in cloudy tears.
Show to the eyes, fill the beholders ears,
With all the lively acts of lustful rage,
Restrained by modest tears, and chastities entreats,
And let king Iohn that ill part personage,
By suits, devices, practices and threats:
And when he sees all serveth to no end,
Of chaste Matilda let him make an end.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: We are all fitted, Friar, shall we begin?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Well art thou suited: would my order would
Permit me habit equal to my heart.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: If you remember, Iohn did take an oath,
Never again to seek Matildaes love.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: O what is he, that is sworn affections slave,
That will not violate all laws, all oaths?
And being mighty, what will he omit,
To compass his intents, though never so ill?
You must suppose king Richard now is dead,
And Iohn (resistless) is fair Englands Lord:
Who striving to forget Matildaes love,
Takes to his wife the beauteous Isabell,
Betrothed to Hugh de Briu, Earl of North March:
And picking quarrels under show of kin,
Wholly divorces his first Queen away:
But yet Matilda, still, still troubles him,
And being in the Court, so oft he courts her,
That by her noble father, old Fitzwater,
She is removed from his lust-tempting eye.
But tides restrained, over swell their bounds with rage:
Her absence adds more fuel to his fire.
In sleep he sees her, and his waking thoughts,
Study by day to compass his desire.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Friar, since now you speak of visions,
It was received by tradition,
From those that were right near unto king Iohn,
Of three strange visions, that to him appeared:
And as I guess, I told you what they were.

sp.speaker: Fri,
sp.l: With them I will begin: draw but that vail,
And there king Iohn sits sleeping in his chair.

div.stage:
Drawe the curten, the king sits sleeping, his sworde by
his side. Enter Austria, before whome commeth Ambition: and bringing him before the chaire, king Iohn, in sleepe, maketh signes to auoid, and holdeth his owne crowne fast with both his hands.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Ambition, that had ever waited on king Iohn,
Now brings him Austria, easy to be taken,
Being wholly tamed by Richards warlike hand,
And bids him add that Dukedom to his crown:
But he puts by Ambition, and contemns
All other kingdoms, but the English crown,
Which he holds fast, as if he would not lose.

div.stage: Enter Constance, leading young Arthur: both offer to take the crowne; but with his foote he ouerturneth them: to them commeth Insurrection, ledde by the F. K. and L. menacing him, and lead the childe againe to the chaire: but he only layeth hand on his sworde, and with his foote ouerthroweth the childe, whome they take vp as deade: and Insurrection flying, they mournefull beare in the bodie.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: The Lady and the child that did ascend,
Striving in vain to take the crown from Iohn,
Were Constance, and her son the Duke of Britaine,
Heir to the elder brother of the king.
Yet he sleeps on, and with a little spurn,
The mother and the Prince doth overturn.
Again when Insurrection them assists,
Stirred by the French king, and the wronged Earl,
Whose troth-plight wife, king Iohn had taken to wife,
He only claps his hand upon his sword,
Mocketh their threatenings, and in their attempts,
The harmless Prince receives recureless death,
Whom they too late with bootless tears lament.

div.stage: Enter Queene, with two children borne after her: she ascends, and seeing no motion, she fetcheth her children one by one; but seeing yet no motion, she descedeth wringing her hands, and departeth. Enter Matilda, in mourning vaile, reading on a booke, at whose comming he starteth, and sitteth vpright: as shee passeth by, hee smiles, and foldes his armes, as if hee did embrace her; being gone, he starts sodainly, and speakes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Matilda, stay Matilda, do but speak:
Who is there? Entreat Matilda to come back.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Who would you have, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why, my Lord Bonuill: I would have Matilda:
That but even now, past by toward the door.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I saw her not my Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hadst thou a lovers eye,
A gnat, a moat, a shadow thou wouldst spy:
Come follow me, she cannot be so far,
But I shall overtake her: come away.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: The last appearance shadowed the fair Queen,
And her two children, at whose sight king Iohn
Showed neither sign nor show of passion:
But when the sun came masked in a cloud,
And vailed beauty, joined with chastity,
Appeared in Matildaes lovely shape,
He starts, he clasps, he wakes, he calls, he seeks
The shadow of that substance he affects:
To her he sews, but she his suit rejects:
To him she sews, but he her suit neglects:
He sues to be her love, she doth despise:
She sues to live a maid, which he denies.
What follows of this wilful will, and shall,
This no and nay, this quenchless, bootless fire,
This cold affection, and this hot desire,
The act itself shall tell, and the poor Friar,
Your partial favours humbly doth require.

div.stage: Exit. Sound trumpets. Enter king, Bonuile, Salsbury, Lore;s.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now I perceive, this only was a dream:
Divine Matildaes Angel did appear,
Decked like a Vestal, ready for heavens quire,
And to this earthly trunk will not come near.
Well, let her go: I must i'faith, I must,
And so I will: kings thoughts should be divine:
So are Matildaes, so henceforth shall mine.

sp.speaker: Old Anb.
sp.l: So doing, peace shall wait upon your crown,
And blessing upon blessing shall befall.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: It is true my Lord, I know full well there shall.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Your people will wax proud of such a king,
That of himself is king, Lord of his thoughts:
Which by assertion of Philosophers,
Is held to be the greatest Empery.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: And they said wisely, noble Aubery.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Then will Fitzwater with his gallant troops,
Again keep triumphs in the English Court.
Then will Matilda

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Matilda, what of her?

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Like a bright star, adorn the lovely train
Of beauteous Ladies, which attend the Queen,
Whose only beauty equalleth them all.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Like an old fool, whose dim eyes wanting sight,
Comparest the sun, to common candle light.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Pardon my liege: I do confess, her fair
Exceeds all these, as far as day doth night.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Grossly alluded: night by moon, by stars,
By wandering sires, exhaled meteors,
By artificial lights, by eyes of beasts,
And little glowworms, glimpsing in the dark,
Hath somewhere brightness, lightness, and sometime
Under each Horizon in all parts clear:
But they at no time, nowhere can be said
To be less dark, than dungeon darkness is.
Pitch coloured, Ebony faced, blacker than black,
While her fair eyes gives beauty to bright day.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: To hear the Queen thus praised works my content.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: The Queen? O, had I such a thought I would repent.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Further my Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What shall we further wade?
I fear I shall be tired with this jade.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: The common-wealth will flourish and increase.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Good Oxford of those things now hold your peace:
And take the pains to fetch in Isabell.
I have strange tidings sent me out of France,
Which she will take, I know, in as good part,
As I accept her praise: fetch her I say.
What is the old fool gone? now go thy way.
What thinkst thou of him Hubert? tell me man.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: As of a good old gentleman my Lord,
That speaks but what he thinks, and thinks you think
As he doth: and I warrant you
Will not conceal those praises from the Queen,
Which as he deems you uttered in her praise.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I would have them believe it so indeed:
But I protest, is no part of my Creed.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: I'faith your Grace did Oxfords years great wrong,
To curtal his good work, that seemed so long:
He peradventure would have brought in more,
After his Preface, to rich plenty's store.
Perchance he would have showed dame vanity,
That in your Court is suffered hourly:
And bad you punish ruffians with long hair,
New fashions, and such toys: a special care
Has that good man: he turns the statute book:
About his hall and chambers if you look,
The moral vertues in fair effigy,
Are lively painted: moral Philosophy
Has not a sentence, be it great or small,
But it is painted on his Honours wall.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Peace, peace, he comes, now let us be silent all.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: I tell you I was proud of his good words.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: God hold them Oxford: for its often seen,
A reconciled foe small good affords.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: O forbear: trust me, I gage my Honour he doth hold you dear.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How cheer you Isabell? The earl, your spouse
Hath sent defiance to the king your husband,
And like a tried tall soldier, fled his holds
In Marchland; Where he knows, despite of him,
And all the men that he therein can raise,
King Iohn could have sent dogs enough to tear
Their ill armed bodies piecemeal, ere his bands
Should with base blood have stained their noble hands.
And whether is this worshipful good Earl
(This first love, old love, new love if you will)
Gone thinks your Ladyship? Forsooth, good man,
To Normandy; and there he stirs up coals,
And urgeth strong aid for confederates,
Who, as he says, are treacherously disposed.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: If he do so, the greater is his sin:
Poor man, I have no interest in him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But he hath had in you, as it should seem,
Else would he not make sonnets of your brow,
Your eye, your lip, your hand, your thigh,
A plague upon him, how came he so nigh?
Nay, now you have the cursed queens counterfeit:
Through rage you shake, because you cannot rave.
But answer me; Why should the Bedlam slave
Entitle a whole Poem to your kiss,
Calling it cherry, ruby, this and this?
I tell you, I am jealous of your love,
Which makes me break into this passion.
Here is the kind noble Aubery de Vere,
Knows what I speak is true:
My Lord, my Lord, I do appeal to you:
Are these things to be borne?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: No by the Rood,
These love-rimes are the tokens of small good.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Why my good Lord, was never Poetry,
Offered unto a Ladies patronage?

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Yes, but not taken.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Yes, and taken too.
Though muddy slaves, whose balladising rimes,
With words unpolished, show their brutish thoughts,
Naming their Maukins in each lustful line:
Let no celestial beauty look awry,
When well writ poems, couching her rich praise,
Are offered to her unstained vertues eye.
For Poetries high spirited sons will raise,
True beauty to all wished eternity:
Therefore my Lord, your age is much to blame,
To think a taken Poem Ladies shame.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: You see the King, that is better read than you,
And far more wronged than I, takes it not well.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Yes but I do: I think not Isabell, Lord,
The worse for any writing of Brunes.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Will you have the troth my Lord? I think so too:
And though I be an old man, by my sword,
My arm shall justify my constant word.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: After a long storm in a troublous sea,
The Pilot is no gladder of a calm,
Than Isabell to see the vexed looks
Of her loved Lord, changed into sweet aspects.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I will not tell thee what a world of foes,
For thy love (dear love) rise against my life.
(Matildaes love: few swords will fight for thee)
I will not number up the many woes
That shall be multiplied, strife upon strife
Will follow; But to shun ensuing ills,
I will take such pledges as shall please me ask,
Of each proud Baron, dwelling in the Realm.
Bruse kinsman, and the deputy to March,
Hath a high-minded Lady to his wife,
An able son for arms, and a less boy,
That is the comfort of his fathers life:
Madam, I know you love the Lady well,
And of her wealth you may be bold to build,
By sending you four hundred white milch kine,
And ten like coloured bulls, to serve that heard:
So fair, that every cow did I seem,
And every bull Europaes ravisher.
To friend myself with such a subjects truth,
Thus I command; You, and Earl Salsbury
Shall, with what speed conveniently ye may,
Hie ye to Gilford, there the Lady lies,
And her sons too, as I am told by spies:
All that she hath, I know she calleth yours,
All that she hath, I gladly would call mine,
If she abuse ye: if she use ye well,
For ever be, what she retains, her own:
Only go by as Queens in progress do,
And send me word how she receiveth you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Well, I avouch she will, before I go,
Far be it, Iohn should prove Lord Bruses foe.
Come noble Oxford, I long to be at Gilford.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: In such a business, Madam, so do I.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go on, good stales, now Gilford is mine own.
Hubert, I charge you take an hundred horse,
And follow unto Gilford Castle gates,
The Queen, pretend, you come to tend upon,
Sent carefully from us: when you are in,
Boldly demand the Lady for her sons,
For pledges of her husbands faith and hers:
Whom when ye have, upon the Castle seize,
And keep it to our use until we come:
Mean while let me alone with Hugh your son,
To work a wonder, if no prodigy:
But, whatsoever, it shall attempted be.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Even that which to your Majesty
May seem contentful, thereto I agree.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go then to Gilford, and a victor be.
Moubray, our mask? are you and Chester ready?

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: We will before your Grace, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How thinkst of it, Mowbray?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: As on a mask; but for our torch-bearers,
Hell cannot rake so mad a crewe as I.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Faith, who is chief?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Will Brand, my Lord.
But then your Grace must curb his cruelty:
The reign once got, he is apt for villainy.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I know the villain is both rough and grim:
But as a tie-dog I will muzzle him.
I will bring him up to fawn upon my friends,
And worry dead my foes. But to our mask.
I mean this night to revel at the feast,
Where fair Matilda graceth every guest:
And if my hidden courtesy she grace,
Old Bainards Castle good Fitzwaters place,
Iohn will make rich, with royal Englands wealth:
But if she do not: not those scattered bands,
Dropping from Austria, and the Holy land,
That boast so much of glorious victories,
Shall stop the inundations of those woes,
That like a deluge I will bring on them:
I know the crew is there, banish all fears:
If wronged, they shall be ours, if welcome, theirs.

div.stage: Exeut Enter Fitzwater and his sonne Bruse, and call forth his daughter.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Why how now votary? still at your book?
Ever in mourning weeds? For shame, for shame,
With better entertainment cheer our friends.
Now by the blessed cross you are much too blame,
To cross our mirth thus; you are much to blame I say.
Good Lord, hath never woe enough of wellada!
Indeed, indeed,
Some sorrow fits: but this is more than need.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Good father pardon me,
You saw I sate the supper and the banquet,
You know I cannot dance, discourse I shun:
By reason that my wit, but small before,
Comes far behind the ripe wits of our age.

sp.speaker: Young B.
sp.l: You will be too ripe for marriage,
If you delay, by day, and day, thus long,
There is the noble Wigmore, lord of the March,
That lies on Wye, Lug, and the Seuerne streams,
His son is like the suns sires Ganimede,
And for your love, hath sent a Lord to plead:
His absence, I did purpose to excuse:
But Lester is the man for him that sues.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.l: My cousin Bruse hath been your Broker, Lester,
At least hath broke the matter to my girl.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: O for a barber at the time of need,
Or one of these that dresses periwigs,
To deck my gray head with a youthful hair:
But I must to it. Matilda, thus it is;
Say, can ye love me? I am Wigmors son.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My cousin said, he looked like Ganimede :
But you, but you.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: But I, but I, you say,
Am rather like old Chremes in a play.
But that is a nice objection: I am he,
But by attorneyship made deputy.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: He is never like to speed well, all his life,
That by attorney sues to win a wife:
But grant you are, whom you seem nothing like,
Young Wigmore, the heir to this noble Lord:
He for his son hath yet sent us never a word.

sp.speaker: Old. Br.
sp.l: If you grant love, when his son doth woo,
Then in your jointure he will send, say, and do.

sp.speaker: Y. Br.
sp.l: And for a dooer, cousin take my word,
Look for a good egg, he was a good bird:
Cock a the game i'faith, never fear.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Aye, but I fear the match will fall out ill,
Because he says his son is named Will.

sp.speaker: Fitz,
sp.l: And why good daughter? Hath some Palmister,
Some Augur, or some dreaming Calculator
(For such I know you often hearken to)
Been prating against the name? Go too, go too,
Do not believe them. Lester, fall to woo.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I must believe my father, and it is you,
That if I ought misdid, reproved me still,
And chiding said, you are wedded to your will.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: God for thy mercy, have ye catched me there?
Wigmore is William, woman. Lester, speak,
Thou art the simplest wooer in the world.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: You have put me out, and she hath took me down:
You with your talk, she with her ready tongue.
You told me I should find her mild and still,
And scarce a word come from her in an hour,
Then did I think, I should have all the talk,
Unhindered by your willingness to help,
Unanswered till I had no more to say: And then

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.l: What then? she with a courtly curtsy saying nay.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your friends attorney might have gone his way,
With as great credit, as did that Orator,
Which handling an Oration, some three hours,
Ill for the matter, worse than bad for phrase:
Having said Dixi; looked, and found not one,
To praise or dispraise his Oration:
For, wearied with his talk, they all were gone.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.l: Now by my troth, if any troth I have,
I am as merry at Matildaes mirth,
As I was glad to see her first days birth.
For till this hour, so help me holy dame,
Since the too timely death of Huntington,
Not a blithe word had passage through her lips.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: See what a pleasing humour wooers bring.

sp.speaker: Cos. B.
sp.l: O but ye leave too soon.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: Yet she avers
I stand too long, shall I choose yours or hers?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Either forbear, I pray ye, for a while.
Welcome Lord Richmond.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: What, doth Matilda smile?
That still like sadness solitary sat:
Then off with widows weeds, and teach your feet,
(That have forgot for want of exercise,
And by the means your sorrow had no mean)
To tread a measure: for a gallant crew,
Of courtly maskers landed at the stairs,
Before whom unentreated, I am come,
And have prevented, I believe, their page,
Who with his torch is entered.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Richmond, thanks:
If you have aught to say about the maskers,
Beseech the Gentlemen to enter in:
For they are welcome guests to old Fitzwate.
Son, son, I pray you fetch the Ladies in:
We have been talking here about a match,
And left our noble friends in discontent.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay by my faith, we had much merriment;
Yet thought it long, you neither came, nor sent.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: How now Matilda? pray thee cheer thee girl.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I thought it was a lightning before death:
Too sudden to be certain: good pleasure stay.
Wilt thou not wanton? churl then go thy way.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: What? changed so soon? so soon fallen to your dups?
Cheerily: the mask comes in. O God, this veil and look
Fit not this sport.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I will leave it.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Nay: for your love, Williams sake, fair maiden stay.

div.stage: Dance: Maskers take each a Ladie, Iohn Matilda: but refusing, father;

sp.l: This is no courtship daughter, be not nice,
You both abuse him and disparage us:
His fellows had the Ladies they did choose,
And well you know, here is no more maids than Maud:
Yourself are all our store: I pray you rise,
Or by my faith, I say you do us wrong.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I will do what you will: lead, lead your dance.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: You know me by my speech.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Aye my Liege, Aye: O! that temptatious tongue
Had nowhere to be placed but in your head.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Well, say I have her tongue, had I not need,
When you have both her eyes: nay all her shape:
Able to tempt even Ioue himself to rape.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Good my Lord leave; or I will leave the place.

div.stage: Daunce againe: and in the first course Matilda flings from him: Iohn followes.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Dance out your Galliard: Gods dear holy bread,
You are too forgetful: dance, or by my troth,
You will move my patience more than I will speak.
sp.stage: She vnwilling, Iohn roughly puls her.
sp.l: Nay soft unmannered sir, you are too rough:
Her joints are weak, your arms are strong and tough:
If ye come here for sport, you welcome be,
If not, better your room than such bad company.
Dost threaten me? then will I see thy face.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: And so thou shalt, look on me rebel Lord;
Thou that wert late a factious ring-leader,
And in the open field gavest me fierce fight,
Art thou again gathering another head,
That with such rudeness thou dost entertain
The gentle coming of thy Sovereign?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: My dread Lord, hear me, and forgive this fault;
What I have erst done, long since you forgave:
If I did lead the Barons in the field,
The Barons chose me, when they could not choose
But make some leader, you were so misled.
When better thoughts entered your royal breast,
We then obeyed you, as our Sovereign head.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You did even what you list, and so do still.
I am the king, but you must have your will:
The plain troth is, we are not come in sport,
Though for our coming, this was our best cloak:
For if we never come, till you do send,
We must not be your guests while banquets last.
Contentious brawls you hourly send to us:
But we may send and send, and you return,
This Lord is sick, that pained with the gout,
He rid from home. You think I find not out
Your close confederacies: yes I do, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: If there be here a close confederate,
Gods vengeance light upon him with my hate.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: No, you are open Lester, that I know.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I by the Lord, my Lord, your open foe.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: By thy Lords Lord, and mine, proud Rafe of Chester,
Thou darest not say so, wert thou from the king.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: Yes, but he dares and shall.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Mowbray, if you stand by,
He dares perchance, else will the dastard fly.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: My own sword shall maintain my tongues true speech:
For it is not frequented to such lies,
As wrangling Lester, and proud Richmond use:
It cannot set out like a thundering drum,
Or roaring Canon, stuffed with naught but brags,
The multitudes of seas died red with blood,
And famous cities into cinders turned,
By their two armed arms.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye Chester,
And then they show us rags, torn off belike,
From poor decayed Ladies petticoats:
For neither bill, nor feathered shot, nor pike
Made half or any of those rents they have:
These patched together, fastened unto staves,
They will not stick to swear, have been advanced
Against the Sophie Souldan, and the Turke.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Do not maintain proud Chester, my lives Liege.
Your words I must put up: his if I bear
Yes you shall bear them, Bear, and yet not bite:
We have you muzzled now: remember once
You braved us with your Bombard boasting words:
Come briefly, Lester, Richmod, both Fitzwaters, Bruse,
Deliver up your swords immediately:
And either yield your bodies to our hands,
Or give such pledges as we shall accept,
Unto our Steward Winchester, with speed.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: I will not leave my arms, nor break my word
Except I be provoked: your liege-man I am sworn:
That oath is pledge enough. If you mislike

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou hearest me say, I do.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: And I reply, that pledge refused, I have no more for you.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: And Richmond says as noble Lester saith;
Already have we plighted fame and faith:
Which being scorned, returns to us again,
And by the kings own mouth, we are discharged.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Fitzwater, what say you?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: What pledge desires my Liege?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I ask your stubborn daughter.

sp.speaker: Yong Br.
sp.l: That were a gage to be engaged.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Peace thou head-strong boy.
Pardon me sovereign: all my power is yours:
My goods you may command, my life you may:
My children too I know with both their lives,
Will readily adventure deaths worst wrongs,
To do such service as true subjects should:
But honourable fame, true chastity

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Make no exceptions, yield her up to me,
Or look for ever for my enmity.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Nay then Fitzwater tells your Majesty,
You do him wrong; and well will let you wit,
He will defend his honour to the death.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And Bruse, you are no otherwise disposed,
You will not give your sons to me for pledge.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: I have but one, being my lesser boy,
Who is at Gilford: for my other son,

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: He braves me with the rest.
Well it is night, and there is no sun to swear by,
But by Gods son: and by him I here protest,
A miserable storm this night to raise,
That shall not cease, while England giveth rest,
To such vile traitors: Bruse I will begin with you:
I will i'faith, as true as God is true.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Then shall a storm be raised against a storm,
And tempest be with tempest beaten back.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: But this firm Island like the sea will toss,
And many goodly buildings go to wrack,
Many a widow weep her dying son,
And many a mother to her helpless babes
Cry out uncomfortably; children peace,
Your crying unto me is all in vain,
Dead is my husband, your poor father slain.

sp.speaker: Yong Br.
sp.l: We can not help it uncle.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: No, you see entreats and humble suits have now no power:
But lust and wrath the kingdom doth devour.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Me he did menace first, and much I fear
He will to Gilford, and besiege my wife.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: O, hie to save her. Richmond ride with him,

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Let us away Bruse, lest we come too late,
And with us take some score of men well armed.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Do: Lester, and myself will keep the city,
Till we are furnished with an able army.
Your Nephew, Bruse, shall take an hundred armed men,
And post to Hartford Castle with your sister:
Sith wrong will wake us, we will keep such watch,
As for his life, he shall not hurt us bring.

div.stage: Enter Queene, Bruses Ladie>, Hubert, Salsbury.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Be comforted good Madam, do not fear,
But give your son as pledge unto the king:
Yourself at Court may keep him company.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: I am betrayed, alas I am betrayed,
And little thought your Highness had been bent,
So much against me, for my many loves,
As to prepare an entrance for my foe.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: As I shall live in heaven, I did not know
Of Huberts coming: but lament not this:
Your son you say is gone; what fear you then?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: O madam, murder, mischief, wrongs of men
I fear, I fear: what is it I do not fear?
Sith hope is so far off, despair so near.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Answer me good Hubert, I pray the Hubert do.
What think you of this matter, may I on your word
Persuade the woman that all things are well?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: You may persuade her, if you can my Lord:
For I protest I know no other thing,
But that the king would have him for a pledge of the
Lord Bruses faith.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: And reason too. Now by my Honour, Hubert, I protest it is good reason.
Bruse, I tell you plain,
Is no sound cloak, to keep Iohn from the rain.
I will go to her.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Do good simple Earl.
If not by threats, nor my entreats she yield,
Thy brain is barren of invention,
sp.p: Dried up with care: and never will she yield her son to thee, that having power, wantest wit.

sp.speaker: Br. Wife.
sp.l: I overhear thee Hubert.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: So do I dame Bruse:
But stir no coals: the man is well beloved,
And merits more than so.

sp.speaker: Bru. W.
sp.l: But I will answer.
Hubert, thou fatal keeper of poor babes,
That are appointed hostages for Iohn,
Had I a son here, as I have not one
(For yesterday I sent him into Wales )
Thinkst thou I would be so degenerate,
So far from kind, to give him unto thee?
I would not I protest: thou knowest my mind.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Lady, you fear more than you need to do,
Indeed you do, in very deed you do:
Hubert is wronged about the thing you mean,
About young Arthus: O, I thought it was so:
Indeed the honest, good, kind gentleman
Did all he might for safeguard of the child.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Believe me Madam Bruse, the man is wronged.

sp.speaker: B. w.
sp.l: But he wrongs me, to keep my Castle thus,
Disarming my true servants, arming his.
Now more of outrage comes, what shall I do?

div.stage: Enter the king, Mowbray, Winchester, Chester.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O this is well. Hubert, where is Bruses son?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Where thou shalt never see him, Iohn.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Lady, we shall have talk with you anon.
Where is he Hubert?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Hid, or fled my Lord: we can by no means get her to confess.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Welcome to Gilford, Oxfords liefest Lord.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You scarce give welcome, ere I bid you go:
For you my Lord, the Queen and Winchester,
Shall march to Harford. Sweet Isabell,
And if thou love me, play the Amazon.
Matilda that hath long bewitched mine eye,
Is as I hear by spials, now in Harford Castle;
Besiege her there: for now her haughty father
Ruffians it up and down, and all the brood
Of viperous traitors whet their poisoned teeth,
That they may feed on us that foster them.
Go forward, and go with you victory:
Which to assure, my powers shall follow you.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Did I not tell you this? then trust me next:
Nay he is changed, and cares no more for her,
Than I do Madam.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be gone I say, be gone:
Your speed, rich victory attendeth on:
But your delay
May give your foes the happy glorious day.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: One boon my Liege, and part.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Be brief.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Show that poor Lady pity, I beseech.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I will indeed. Come Lady, let us in.
You have a son, go in and bring him me,
And for the Queens sake I will favour ye.

sp.speaker: B. W.
sp.l: I have no son: come, come: come in and search,
And if you find him, wretched may I be.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Chester and Hubert, see you keep good watch.
Not far off do I hear a warlike sound:
Bruse on my life: look to it while I go in
To seek this boy; for needs we must have him.
Come with us Mowbray.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: The Castle gates are shut. what ho? what ho?
You that are servants to the Lady Bruse ,
Arise, make entrance for your Lord and friends.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: We will make issue ere ye enter here.
Who have we there, Richmond and Bruse? Is it you?
What, up so soon, are ye so early here?
In you i'faith the Proverb is verified:
You are early up, and yet are never the near.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: The worse our fortune. Bruse let us go hence,
We have no power to fight, nor make defence.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What Richmond, will you prove a Runaway?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: From thee good Winchester: Now the Lord defend.

sp.speaker: Bruse.
sp.l: we will stay and fight.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: It is to no end: we have but twenty men, and they be tired.
But ere we do retire, tell me Lord Hubert,
Where are my wife and son?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Your wife is here, your son we cannot find.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Let son and wife, high heavens, your comfort find.

div.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter King, Mowbray, Ladie Bruse.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Bruse hath been here, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Aye, let him go: we have good pledges: though we see but one,
The other we are sure will come anon.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: I do advise you, for your own discharge,
Deliver up your son unto the king.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay let her choose. Come hither Mowbray.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: The king is angry; Lady Bruse advise you.

sp.speaker: L. Br.
sp.p: What? be advised by thee, to have my loving, kind and pretty boy, given to an unkind killer of sweet boys?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Madam go too, take counsel of your friends,
I warrant you the king will use him well.

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.l: Aye, as he used his Nephew, Arthur Chester:
God bless my child from being used so.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: Sir Hubert, what are all the people voided,
The horses and the cattle turned forth?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Mowbray, they be.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: Then will I do the kings commandment.

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.l: What will he do! good lord, what will he do!
Mowbray, I pray you what is it you will do.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Why? fire the Castle.

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.l: The Castle Mowbray? tarry, tarry man,
Hold me not Chester, gentle Mowbray stay:
Good Hubert let me go.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.p: You must not go: the king is moved and will not hear you speak.

sp.speaker: L. Br.
sp.p: But he shall hear me. Pity me king Iohn, call Mowbray back: hear me for pities sake, regard the Lady Bruses woeful cry.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What dost thou ask?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: First call back Mowbray.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Stay Mowbray: now be brief,

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: I have some linen garments, jewels, tyres,
Packed in a hamper here within the lodge:
O let me save it from consuming fire.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And is this all?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: It is all the little all, I here have left.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away, set fire; linen and trash.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: O once more hear me, there is a precious Gem,
You have not any richer in all the Realm:
If fire do blemish it, Art never more,
To his true colour, can the same restore.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Fetch it: two of ye help her with her hamper hither.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nay, nay: one will suffice: the Jewel if I save, is all I ask.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: We shall her Jewel have.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: She is very fearful I should keep her son.
Ye do, ye do.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Alas good Lady: hark, Chester and she are chiding.

div.stage: Enter Chester and she, leading the boy.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Let go his hand. Is this a paw, think you,
To hold a tender hand in? fie for shame:
A noble man so churlish? Look I pray,
His arms are gristles.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now Lady Bruse
Doth Chester hurt the Jewel of your joy?
Now by my troth it is a pretty boy.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I: knew your Majesty as much as I, you would. say more.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Well, he and you of us no wrong shall have:
But stay in Windsor Castle with sir Walter Blunt,
And honourably be used: provided still,
Your husband and your son obey our will.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: For this great mercy, if they disobey,
Myself will chide them. Fortune follow Iohn,
And on his foes fall swift destruction.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Come let us now after the Queen and Oxford.

div.stage:
Exeunt omnes.
Enter the Queene, Oxford, Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Now are ye, worthy and resolved men,
Come to the cage where the unclean birds bide,
That tire on all the fair flight in the Realm.
Summon this Castle, or (to keep my words)
This cage of night-hid owls, light-flying birds.

div.stage: Offer to summon. Enter yong Bruse, Matilda, Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Stay drum: thou needest not summon willing men:
Or rather wilful: for such me think they be.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: See ye yon baggage, muffled in black weeds?
Those clouds fold in the Comet, that portends
Sad desolation to this royal Realm:
For ever seek to mask her light, good friends.
Let us disrobe her of each little beam,
And then your Phoebus will one Phoebe have,
That while they live shall lend your land true light,
Give joy unto your day, rest to your night.
Assail them: stay not.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Stay, and assay them first.
I say to you, fair Queen, this fact is foul.
Let not provoking words whet dull edged swords:
But try if we can blunt sharpe blades with words.
Fitzwaters Nephew, Bruse, I see thee there,
And tell thee, it is shame for such a boy,
To lead a many able men to fight.
And modest looking maid, I see you too:
And unfit sight, to view virginity
Guarded with other soldiers, than good prayers:
But you will say the king occasions it.
Say what you will, no king but would take cause
Of just offence: yield you young Bruse: your mother is in hold.
Yield you young maid: your father is in hold.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Will the Queen keep me from the lustful king?
Then will I yield.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: A plague upon this counterfeiting quean.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Gods blessed mercy, will you still be mad,
And wrong a noble virgin with vile speech?

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Let me alone: Matilda, maiden fair,
Thou virgin spouse, true Huntingtons just heir,
Wilt thou come hither? and I do protest,
The Queen and I, to mitigate this war,
Will do what thou wouldest have.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I come.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: You shall not go: sound drums to war.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Alack, alack for woe: well God for us, sith it will needs be so.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: What stay you for?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Matildaes cries do stay us.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oxford , I come in hope of thy defence.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: First will I die, ere you shall yield yourself,
To any coward Lord that serves the King.
