sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: And thou shalt rue in earnest this rude jest.

div.stage: Fight againe, Matilda taken, led by the haire by two Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Rude hands, how hale you virtuous honour forth?
You do not well: away: now by my faith,
Ye do not well I say.
Take her, fair Queen, use her as she deserves:
She is fair, she is noble, chaste, and debonair.
I must, according to due course of war,
See that our soldiers scatter not too fare,
Lest what care won, our negligence may lose.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Is this the Helen, this the Paragon,
That makes the English Ilinnus flame so fast?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I am not she, you see I am not she:
I am not ravished yet, as Helen was,
I know not what will come of Iohns desire,
That rages like the sea, that burns like fire.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Plain Iohn, proud Ione? I will tear your painted face: thus, thus I will use you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Do, do, what you will.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: How goes this gear? ha? foul fall so foul a deed,
Poor chaste child of Fitzwater dost thou bleed.
By Gods blessed mother this is more than need:
And more I tell you true than I would bear,
Were not the danger of the camp so near.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: My Lord, the foes have gathered head:
Lord Bruse the father, joineth with the son.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Why here is the matter, we must spend our time,
To keep your nails from scratching innocence,
Which should have been bestowed for our defence.
What shall we now do! help me holy God,
The foe is come, and we are out of rank.

div.stage: Skirmish: Queene taken, Matilda rescued. Enter olde Bruse wounded, led by his sonne and Lester.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Is the field ours?

sp.speaker: Young B.
sp.l: Aye, thanks to noble Lester.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Give God thanks, son, be careful to thy mother:
Commend me to Fitzwater, love thy brother,
If either arms, or prayers may him recover.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: How cheers old Bruse?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: His soul to joy is fled:
His grief is in my bosom buried.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: His life was dearly bought. For my eyes saw
A shambles of dead men about his feet,
Sent by his sword unto eternal shade:
With honour bury him: cease tears good Bruse.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Tears help not I confess: yet must I weep.
Soldiers, your help to bear him to my tent.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Be comforted great Queen: forget my wrongs.
It was my fortune, and no fault of yours.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Is she thus mild? or doth she mock my chance?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Queen Elianor, are you a prisoner?
See what it is to be a soldier.
But what foul hand hath harmed Matildaes fair?
Speak honourable maid: who tore thy hair?
Did Oxford or the Queen this violence?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Ungentle grooms first took and tore me thus:
From whom old Oxford, chastising their wrong,
Most kindly brought me to this gentle Queen:
Who laid her soft hand on my bleeding cheeks,
Gave kisses to my lips, wept for my woe:
And was devising how to send me back,
Even when your last alarum frighted us:
And by her kindness, fell into your hands.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Which kindness we return. Madam, be free.
Soldiers, conduct the Queen whether she please.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Farewell Matilda: if I live, believe,
I will remember this. O how I grieve,
That I should wrong so innocent a maid.
Come Lady, old Fitzwater is not far:
He will weep to see these scars, full well I know.

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: Would I were from this woeful world of war:
Sure I will scape, and to some Nunnery go.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Had you her then? had you her in your power?

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: aye marry had we; we had taken her.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: O had she been in mine,
Not all earths power, from my power, should have freed her.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: You are a king: and high are Princes thoughts:
It may be with your sight you could have chased
An host of armed men: it may be so:
But we your subjects did the best we could:
Yet Bruse the father, backing Bruse the son,
Scattered our troops: brought rescue to Matilda ,
And took your peerless Queen, their prisoner.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: On all the race of Bruses, for this wrong,
I will have vengeance. Hubert, call in Brand.
My Lord of Oxford, give us leave a while to be alone.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: I will my liege: but be you comforted,
The Queen will be recovered, do not fear,
As well as ever she was;

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Oxford, forbear I pray.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Yet for the wrong she did unto Matilda, I fear, I fear.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The father and the son did rescue her:
The mother and the son shall rue the deed:
So it shall be: I am resolved thereon.
Matilda, my souls food, those have bereft:
And these of bodies food I will bereave.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Will Brand?

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Your Majesty.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Less of your curtsy. Hubert, stand aside.
Post speedily to Windsor: take this ring:
Bid Blunt deliver Bruses wife and child,
Into your hands: and ask him for the key
Of the dark tower, over the dungeon vault:
In that, see you shut up the dam and brat.
Pretend to Blunt that you have left them meat,
Will serve some seven-night: and unto him say,
It is my will you bring the key away.
And here you sir, I charge you on your life,
You do not leave a bit of bread with them.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: I warrant you, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Come back again with all the speed you may.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: Some cruel task is pointed for that slave,
Which he will execute as cruelly.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: No ruth, no pity shall have harbour here,
Till fair Matilda be within these arms.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Comfort my Lord, comfort my gracious Lord.
Your love is come again.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Ah Oxford, where?

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Here my dread Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou liest, she is not there.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Under correction you wrong my age.
Say I beseech you, is not this the Queen?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I cry you mercy Oxford, it is indeed.
Where is Matilda?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Where virtue, chastity, and innocence remain, there is Matilda.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How comes she, pray, to be so chaste, so fair, so virtuous in your eye?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: She freed me from my foes, and never urged
My great abuse, when she was prisoner.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What did you to her?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Railed upon her first,
Then tare her hair, and rent her tender cheeks.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: O heaven! was not the day dark at that foul deed?
Could the sun see, without a red eclipse,
The purple tears fall from those tyrant wounds!
Out AEthiope, Gypsy, thick lipped Blackamoor:
Wolf, Tigress, worse than either of them both.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Are you advised my lord?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Out doting Earl.
Couldst thou endure to see such violence?

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: I tell you plain my Lord, I brooked it not,
But staid the tempest.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Rend my loves cheeks? that matchless Effigy,
Of wonder-working, natures chiefest work.
Tear her rich hair? to which, gold wires,
Suns rays, and best of best compares
(In their most pride) have no comparison.
Abuse her name? Matildaes sacred name?
O barbarous outrage, rudeness merciless.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I told you Oxford, you mistook the king.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: I did indeed: my liege Lord give me leave,
To leave the Camp.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Away old fool: and take with thee that trull:
For if she stay,

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Come Lady, come away.
Tempt not his rage: ruin wrath always brings:
Lust being lord, there is no trust in kings.

sp.speaker: Mou.
sp.l: To arms king Iohn: Fitzwaters field is pitched,
About some mile hence, on a campaign plain.
Chester hath drawn our soldiers in array:
The wings already have begun the fight.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thither we will with wings of vengeance fly,
And win Matilda, or lose victory.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why did my keeper put us in thy hands?
Wherein have we offended Blunt or thee?

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: You need not make these words:
You must remove your lodging: this is all.
Be not afeared: come come, here is the door.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.l: O God how dark it is!

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.l: Go in go in: it is higher up the stairs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My trembling heart forbids me to go in.
O if thou have compassion, tell me true,
What my poor boy and I must trust unto?

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: I tell thee true, compassion is my foe:
Yet have I had of thee compassion.
Take in thy child: as I have faith or troth,
Thou and thy boy shall be but prisoners:
And I must daily bring you meat and drink.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well, thou hast sworn: and God so give thee light,
As in this dark place thou rememberest us.
Poor heart, thou laughest, and hast not wit to think,
Upon the many fears that me afflict.
I will not in: help us, assist us Blunt,
We shall be murdered in a dungeon.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Cry without cause? I will have ye in i'faith.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O let my boy and I but dine with Blunt,
And then I will with patience go in.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Will ye, or nill ye, 'swounds, ye must go in,
And never dine.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What sayst thou? never dine?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No not with Blunt, I mean. Go in I say:
Or by this hand, ye get no meat today.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My child is hungry. When shall he have meat?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Why, if ye would go in, immediately.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I will go in: but very much I doubt,
Nor I, nor my poor boy shall ever come out.

div.stage: Exit. Hee seemes to locke a doore.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Never while ye live, i'faith: now are they sure.
Cry till their hearts ache, no man can them hear.
A miserable death is famishment:
But what care I? the king commanded me.

div.stage: Alarum within: excursions. Enter Fitzwater, Bruse.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Now doth fair fortune offer hope of speed:
But howsoever we speed: good cousin Bruse,
March with three hundred bows and pikes to Windsor,
Spreading a rumour that the day is ours:
As ours it shall be, with the help of heaven.
Blunt loves our part far better than the kings:
And will, I gage my life, upon the news,
Surrender up the Castle to our use.
By this means shall you help us to a hold,
How ever it chance, set free your Lady mother
That lives in prison there, with your young brother.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Away good uncle, to the battle go:
But that a certain good ensues I know,
For all the world, I would not leave you so.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Away, away.
God send thee Windsor: us this happy day.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: You cannot hide yourself Matilda: no disguise
Will serve the turn: now must you to the king:
And all these wars will with your presence cease.
Yield you to him, he soon will yield to peace.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: They say thou tookest some pity of a child,
The king appointing thee to sear his eyes.
Men do report thee to be just of word,
And a dear lover of my Lord the king.
If thou didst that, if thou be one of these:
Pity Matilda, prostrate at thy feet.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: I saved young Arthurs eyes, and pity thee:
My word is just, which I have given the king.
The King I love: and thee I know he loves.
Compare these: then how can I pleasure thee?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: By letting me escape to Dunmow Abbey,
Where I will end my life a votary.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: And the king die with doting on thy love.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, no: this fire of lust would be soon laid,
If once he knew me sworn a holy maid.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Thy tears and love of virtue have the power
To make me, at an instant, true and false:
True to distressed beauty and rare chastity:
False to king Iohn, that holds the sight of thee
Dearer than England, or earths Empery.
Go happy soul, that in so ill an age,
Hast such fair beauty for thy heritage:
Yet go not so alone. Dost hear tall soldier?
I know thee honest: guide this gentle maid,
To Dunmow Abbey: she is one I know.
I will excuse thee and content thee well.
My signet take, that ye may pass unsearched.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Kind Hubert, many prayers, for this good deed,
Shall on my beads be daily numbered.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: O treble heat of honour, toil and rage!
How cheers earl Richmond?
Fitzwater, speak old man.
We are now near together; answer me.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Lester, the more our woe,
The likelier to be taken by the foe.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: O let not such a thought abuse thy age:
We will never yield us to the tyrants rage.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: But if my girl be yielded,

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: If she be.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Aye, Aye: there is no man but shall have his time to die.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Now is our hour: which they shall dearly buy.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Lester, we will stand like three Battalions:
What says our noble General thereto?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Why, I say do: while I can, I will keep my place with you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now my bugbear, will ye now submit?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: To death, but not to thee.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Richmond, nor you?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Earl Richmond will not yield.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Methinks Fitzwater, you should have more wit.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: If it be wit to live, I have no will:
And so in this, my will over-rules my wit.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Alarum then, with weapons will
We scourge your desperate will, and teach ye to have wit.

div.stage:
Fight: driue back the king.
Withdrawe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Of high heroic spirits be they all:
We will withdraw a little and confer:
For they are circled round, and cannot scape.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: O that we three, who in the suns arise,
Were (like the three Triumvirates of Rome)
Guides of an host, able to vanquish Rome,
Are now alone, enclosed with enemies!

sp.speaker: Fitz,
sp.l: The glory of the world hath no more stay:
But as it comes, it fleets, and fades away.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Courage, and let us die; they come again:
It is Lord Hugh Burgh alone, Hughberr, what news?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: This days fierce slaughter, Iohn, our King, laments:
And to you three, great leaders of an host,
That now have not a man at all to lead:
You worthy captains without companies

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Fitzwater, Richmond; by the blessed Sun,
Lord Hubert mocks us.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: By the Moon I do not, and put the blessed to it.
It is as good an oath as you have sworn.
My heart grieves, that so great hearts, as yours be,
Should put your fortunes on a sort of slaves,
That bring base fear within them to the field:
But to the matter. Sith your state is such,
That without mercy you are sure of death
(Which I am sure, and well his Highness knows,
You do not fear at all) yet he gives grant,
On just conditions you shall save your lives.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: On no condition will I save my life,
Except Matilda be returned again,
Unblemished, unabused; and then I yield.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: She now is where she never will return.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Never? O God! is my Matilda dead?

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: Dead to the world: dead to this woe she is.
She lives at Dunmow, and is vowed a Nun.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Do not delude me Hubert, gentle son.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: By all the faith and honour of my kin:
By my unstained allegiance to the king:
By my own word, that hath reprooveless been,
She is at Dunmow.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: O, how came she there?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: When all these fields were walks for rage and fear
(This, howling like a head of hungry wolves:
That, scudding as a heard of frighted deer)
When dust arising like a cole black fog,
From friend divided friend, joined foe to foe:
Yet neither those, nor these could either know,
Till here and there through large wide mouthed wounds
Proud life, even in the glory of his heat,
Losing possession, belched forth streams of blood:
Whose spouts in falling, made ten thousand drops,
And with that purple shower the dust allayed:
At such a time met I the trembling maid,
Seeming a dove, from all her fellows parted.
Seen, known, and taken: unseen and unknown,
To any other that did know us both,
At her entreats I sent her safely guided,
To Dunmow Abbey: and the guide returned,
Assures me she was gladfully received,
Pitied: and in his sight did take her oath.

sp.speaker: Fitz
sp.l: Hubert, for this thy honourable deed,
I and my house will reverence thy name.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Yet, I beseech you, hide it from the King:
At least that I conveyed her to the place.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Hubert, I will.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: What, stand they still on terms?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: On honourable terms, on terms of right.
Our lives without our liberty we scorn.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You shall have life and liberty, I swear.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Then Lester bows his knee to his liege Lord,
And humbly begs his Highness to beware
Of wronging innocence, as he hath done.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: The like Richmond desires; and yields his sword.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I do embrace ye both, and hold myself
Richer by a whole Realm, in having you.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Much is my wrong: yet I submit with these,
Begging free leave, to live a private life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Old brands of malice in thy bosom rest.
Thou shalt have leave to leave me, never doubt.
Fitzwater, see thou ship thee straight for France,
And never set thy foot on English shore,
Till I repeal thee. Go, go hence in peace.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Why doth your Highness wrong Fitzwater thus?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I right his wrong; he is weary of the land.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Not of the land, but of a public life.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Content ye Lords: in such quick times as these,
We must not keep a drone among our bees.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I am as glad to go, as you to send:
Yet I beseech this favour of your Grace,
That I may see Matilda ere I part.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Matilda? See Matilda, if thou canst
Before Sun set; stay not another day.
The Abbey walls, that shroud my happy child,
Appear within her hapless fathers sight.
Farewell my Sovereign. Lester, Richmond, Lords:
Farewell to all: grief gives no way to words.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fitzwater stay: Lords, give us leave a while.
Hubert, go you before unto the Abbess,
And signify our coming; let her bring
Matilda to her father. Come old man;
Be not too froward, and we shall be friends.
About this girl our mortal jars began:
And if thou wilt, here all our quarrel ends.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Reserve my honour, and my daughters fame,
And no poor subject that your Grace commands,
Shall willinger submit, obey, and serve.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Do then but this; Persuade thy beauteous child,
To leave the Nunnery and return to Court:
And I protest from henceforth to forswear
All such conceits of lust as I have borne.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I will, my Lord, do all that I may do:
But give me leave, in this, to doubt of you.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This small thing grant, and ask me any thing:
Or else die in exile, loathed of the King.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: You shall perceive I will do what I may.

div.stage: Enter, on the wall, Abbesse, Matilda.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Matilda is afraid to leave the house:
But lo, on yonder battlement she stands:
But in no case will come within your hands.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What? will my Lady Abbess wars with us:
Speak Lady: wherefore shut you up your gates?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Have we not reason, when an host of men,
Hunt and pursue religious chastity?
King Iohn, bethink thee what thou takest in hand,
On pain of interdiction of thy Land.
Murderers and felons may have sanctuary:
And shall not honourable maids distressed,
Religious virgins, holy Nuns professed,
Have that small privilege? Now out upon thee, out.
Holy Saint Catherine shield my virginity:
I never stood in such extremity.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: My Lord, the Abbess lies, I warrant you:
For I have heard, there is a Monk of Bury ,
That once a weak comes thither to make merry.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Content thee Hubert, that same monk and she,
If the worst come, my instruments shall be.
Good Lady Abbess, fear no violence:
There is not one here shall offer you offence.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Daughter, all this while tears my speech have staid.
My Lord the King: Lords all draw near I pray:
And hear a poor man's parting from his child.
Matilda, still my unstained honours joy,
Fair Ornament of old Fitzwaters coat,
Born to rich fortunes, did not this ill age
Bereave thee of thy birth-rights heritage.
Thou seest our Sovereign, Lord of both our lives,
A long besieger of thy chastity,
Hath scattered all our forces, slain our friends,
Raced our Castles, left us never a house
Wherein to hide us from his wrathful eye:
Yet God provides; France is appointed me:
And thou findest house-room in this Nunnery.
Here if the king should dote, as he hath done,
It is sacrilege to tempt a holy Nun:
But I have hope he will not: yet my fear
So drowns my hope, as I am forced to stay,
And leave abruptly, what I more would say.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O go not yet, my grieved hearts comforter,
I am as valiant to resist desire,
As ever thou wert worthy in the field.
Iohn may attempt: but if Matilda yield,
O then.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Aye then Matilda, thou dost lose
The former glory of thy chaste resolves.
These seven years hast thou bid a Martyrs pains,
Resisting in thyself lust-growing tier:
For being mortal, sure thou hadst desire.
And five sad winters have their full course run,
Since thou didst bury noble Huntington.
In these years, many months, and many days,
Have been consumed, thy vertues to consume:
Gifts have been heralds, Panders did presume
To tempt thy chaste ears, with their unchaste tongues:
All in effect, working to no effect.
For I was still the watchman of thy tower,
The keeper of foul worms, from my fair flower:
But now, no more, no more Fitzwater may
Defend his poor Lamb, from the Lions prey:
Thy order and thy holy prayers may.
To help thee, thou hast privilege by law:
Therefore be resolute, and nobly die,
Abhor base lust, defend thy chastity.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Dispatch Fitzwater, hinder not thy child:
Many preferments do on her await.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Aye girl, I know thou shalt be offered wealth
(Which is a shrewd enticement in sad want)
Great honours to lift up thy low estate,
And glorious titles to eternize thee.
All these do but gild over ugly shame:
Such wealth, my child, foreruns releaseless need:
Such honour ever proves dishonourate.
For titles, none comes near a virtuous name:
O keep it ever, as thou hast done yet.
And though these dark times should forget thy praise,
An age will come, that shall eternize it.
Bid me farewell, and speak it in a word.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Farewell dear father.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: O farewell sweet child.
My Liege farewell: Lester, Richmond, Hughbert,
Chester, and Mowbray: friends and foes farewell.
Matilda, see thou keep thy spotless fame,
And live eternized; else die soon with shame.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Amen, amen, father, adieu, adieu:
Grief dwells with me, sweet comfort follow you.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Come daughter come: this is a woeful sight,
When good endeavours are oppressed by might.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Ah Hubert, seest thou not the sun go down,
Cloudy and dark? Matilda, stay one word.
She shakes her head, and scornfully says nay.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: How cheerest thou Lester?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Mad man, at my state:
That cannot raise true honour ruinate.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I will not be disdained: I vow to see
Quick vengeance on this girl, for scorning me.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Young Bruse, my Lord, hath gotten Windsor castle,
Slain Blunt your Constable, and those that kept it:
And finding in a tower his mother dead,
With his young brother starved and famished:
That everyone may see the rueful sight,
In the thick wall he a wide window makes:
And as he found them, so he lets them be
A spectacle to every comer by,
That heaven and earth, your tyrant shame may see.
All people cursing, crying fie upon
The tyrant merciless, inhumane Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Chester, and Mowbray, march away to Windsor:
Suppress that traitor Bruse. What if his dam,
In wilful fury, would receive no meat,
Nor suffer her young child any to eat,
Is it our fault? Haste ye with speed away,
And we will follow: go, be gon I pray.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: O black and woeful deed! O piteous thing,
When slaves attend the fierce thoughts of a king.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: My Lord, shall we go too?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Lester and Richmond, Aye: I pray ye do.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Get I my Bear and ragged staff once more
Raised in the field, for these wrongs some shall roar.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Fetch in the Monk of Bury, that I talked off,
And bid Will Brand, my instrument of death,
Come likewise in. Convert, to raging hate,
My long resisted love. Welcome good Monk.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Thanks to my Liege.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thou hast been long in suit,
To be installed Abbot of your house:
And in your favour many friends have stirred.
Now is the hour that you shall be preferred,
Upon condition, and the matter small.
Short shrift to make, good honest Confessor,
I love a fair Nun, now in Dunmow Abbey.
The Abbess loves you, and you pleasure her.
Now if, between you two, this pretty Lady
Could be persuaded to affect a king,
Your suit is granted; and on Dunmowe Abbey,
I will bestow a hundred marks a year.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: A holy Nun, a young Nun, and a Lady.
Dear ware my Lord; yet bid you well as may be:
Strike hands; a bargain, she shall be your own:
Or if she will not

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Nay, if she do refuse,
I will send a deaths-man with you, this is he:
If she be wilful, leave her to his hands:
And on her own head be her hasted end.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: The matter shall be done.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Sirrah, what poisons have you ready?

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Store, store.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Await on the monk then, and ere we take horse,
I will give you such instructions as you need.
Hughbert, prepare to Windsor with our host.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Your tyrannies have lost my love almost:
And yet I cannot choose but love eternally
This wanton king, replete with cruelty.
O how are all his princely vertues stained,
With lust abhorred, and lascivious heat!
Which kindling first to fire, now in a flame,
Shows to the whole world clearly his foul shame.
To quench this flame, full many a tide of tears,
Like overflowing full seas, have been spent:
And many a dry land drunk with human blood;
Yet nothing helps his passions violent:
Rather they add oil to his raging fire,
Heat to his heat, desire to his desire.
Somewhat I fear, is now a managing.
For that prodigious bloody stigmatic,
Is never called unto his kingly sight,
But like a Comet he portendeth still
Some innovation, or some monstrous act,
Cruel, unkindly, horrid, full of hate:
As that vile deed at Windsor, done of late.
Gentle Matilda somewhat I mistrust:
Yet thee I need not fear, such is his love;
Again, the place doth give thee warrantise:
Yet I remember when his Highness said,
The lustful monk of Bury should him aid:
Aye so it is; if she have any ill,
Through the lewd shaveling will her shame be wrought.
If it so chance, Matildaes guiltless wrong
Will with the loss of many a life be bought.
But Hubert will be still his dread Lords friend,
However he deserves, his master serve:
Though he neglect, him will not I neglect:
Whoever fails him, I will Iohn affect.
For though kings fault in many a foul offence,
Subjects must sue, not mend with violence.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Now by my faith, you are to blame Madam:
Ever tormenting ever vexing you?
Cease off these fretting humours, pray ye do.
Grief will not mend it, naught can pleasure you,
But patient suffering: nor by your Graces leave,
Have you such cause to make this hue and cry
After a husband; you have not in good sooth.
Yearly a child? this payment is not bad.
Content fair Queen, and do not think it strange,
That kings do sometimes seek delight in change:
For now and then, I tell you, poor men range.
Sit down a little, I will make you smile.
Though I be now like to the snowy Alps,
I was as hot as AEtna in my youth:
All fire i'faith, true heart of oak, right steel,
A ruffian Lady: often for my sport,
I to a lodge of mine did make resort,
To view my deer I said; dear God can tell,
It was my keepers wife, whom I loved well.
My Countess (God be with her) was a shrew,
As women be, your Majesty doth know:
And some odd pickthank put it in her head,
All was not well: but such a life I led,
And the poor keeper, and his smoothed faced wife,
That will I, nil I, there she might not bide:
But for the people I did well provide:
And by gods mother, for my Ladies spite,
I tricked her in her kind, I served her right.
Were she at London, I the country kept;
Come thither, I at London would sojourn:
Came she to court, from court I straightaway stepped:
Return, I to the court would back return.
So this way, that way, every way she went,
I still was retrograde, seld opposite:
Till at the last, by mildness and submission,
We met, kissed, joined, and here left all suspicion.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Now out upon you Vere, I would have thought,
The world had not contained a chaster man.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Now, by my fay, I will be sworn, I am.
In all I tell you, I confess no ill,
But that I curbed a froward woman's will:
Yet had my Keepers wife been of my mind,
There had been cause some fault with us to find:
But I protest, her noes and nays were such,
That for my life she ever kept go much.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You would take nay: but our king Iohn says no:
No nay, no answer will suffice his turn:
He, for he cannot tempt true chastity,
Fills all the Land with hostile cruelty.
Is it not shame, he that should punish sin,
Defend the righteous, help the innocent,
Carves with his sword, the purpose of his will,
Upon the guarders of the virtuous,
And hunts admired spotless maiden-head,
With all the darts of desolation,
Because she scorneth to be dissolute.
Me, that he leaves, I do not murmur at:
That he loves her, doth no whit me perplex,
If she did love him, or myself did hate:
But this alone is it that me doth vex,
He leaves me that loves him, and her pursues,
That loath him and loves me; how can I choose,
But sadly grieve, and mourn in my green youth?
When nor of her, nor me he taketh ruth.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Have done, good Queen, for gods good love, have don.
This raging humour will no doubt be staid.
Virtuous Matilda is professed a Nun:
Within a mile, at Dunmow lives the maid:
God will not suffer anything so vile:
He will not sure, that he should her defile.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Nor Church, nor chapel, Abbey, Nunnery,
Are privileged from his intemperance.
But leave we him, and let us, I entreat,
Go visit fair Matilda: much I am
In debt unto the maid.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: You are indeed.
You wronged her, when with blows you made her bleed.
But if you please to visit her, fair dame,
Our coach is ready: we will soon be there.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thanks Oxford; and with us I mean to bear
The beauteous garland, sent me out of Spaine:
Which I will offer in the Abbey chapel:
As witness of Matildaes chastity:
Whom while I live, I ever vow to love,
In recompense of rash and causeless wrong.

div.stage: Enter Brand solus, with cuppe, bottle of poyson.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Good, by this hand: exceeding, passing good.
The dog no sooner drank it, but, yugh, yugh quoth he:
So grins me with his teeth: lies down, and dies.
Yughst quoth I? by gogs blood go thy ways:
Of all thy line and generation,
Was never dog so worshipped as thou art.
For ere thou didst, thou wert an officer:
I lie not, by these nails, a squires place:
For the vile cur became a countess taster.
So died the dog. Now in our next account
The Countess comes, let us see a Countess and a Nun.
Why so? why so?
What would she have the whole world quite undone?
We will meet her for that trick. What, not a king?
Hanging is too good for her; I am but a plain knave,
And yet should any of these no forsooths,
These pray aways, these trip and goes, these tits,
Deny me: now by these:
A plague upon this bottle and this cup:
I cannot act mine oath: but to it again.
By these ten ends of flesh and blood, I swear:
First with this hand, wound thus about her hair,
And with this dagger lustily lambacked:
I would i'faith, Aye, by my villainy,
I would: but here, but here she comes,
Led by two doctors in sweet lechery:
If they speed, with my poison I go by;
If not, have at you maid: then steppe in I.

div.stage: Enter Matilda, betweene the Monke and the Nunne.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: And as I said, fair maid, you have done well,
In your distress, to seek this holy place:
But tell me truly, how do you expel
The rage of lust-arising heat in you?

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: By prayer, by fasting, by considering
The shame of ill, and meed of doing well.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: But daughter, daughter, tell me in my ear,
Have you no fleshly fightings now and then?

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Fleshly quoth you? a maid of threescore years,
And fleshly fightings sticking in her teeth?
Well wench, thou art matched i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: You do confess the king hath tempted you,
And thinking now and then on gifts and state,
A glowing heat hath proudly puffed you up:
But thanks to God, his Grace hath done you good.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Who, the kings Grace?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: No: Gods Grace, holy monk.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: The kings Grace fain would do you good, fair maid.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Ill good: he means my fame to violate.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Well, let that be.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Good bawd, good mother B.
How fain you would that that good deed should be!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I was about to say somewhat upon a thing. O thus it is.
We maids that all the day are occupied,
In labour and chaste hallowed exercise,
Are nothing so much tempted while day lasts,
As we are tried and proved in the night.
Tell me Matilda, had you since you came,
No dreams, no visions, nothing worth the note?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: No, I thank God.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Truly you will, you will;
Except you take good heed and bless youself.
For if I lie but on my back a while,
I am past recovery, sure of a bad dream.
You see yon reverend Monk: now God he knows,
I love him dearer for his holiness:
And I believe the devil knows it too:
For the foul fiend comes to me many a night,
As like the monk, as if he were the man.
Many a hundred nights, the Nuns have seen:
Pray, cry, make crosses, do they what they can.
Once gotten in, then do I fall to work,
My holy water bucket being near hand,
I whisper secret spells, and conjure him,
That the foul fiend hath no more power to stand:
He down, as I can quickly get him laid,
I bless myself, and like a holy maid,
Turn on my right side: where I sleep all night,
Without more dreams, or troubling of the sprite,

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: An Abbess! by the cross of my good blade,
An excellent mother to bring up a maid,
For me I mean, and my good master, Iohn :
But never any for an honest man.
Now fie upon that word of honesty:
Passing my throat, it had almost choked me:
'Sblood I will forswear it for this trick.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: We trifle time. Fair maid, it is thus in brief;
This Abbey by your means may have relief:
An hundred marks a year: answer I pray,
What will you do herein?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Even all I may.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: It is charitably spoken, my fair child:
A little thing of yours, a little help
Will serve the turn; learn but to bear, to bear
The burden of this world, and it will do.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Well go thy ways: Is this no bawd think you?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Madam, the heavy burden of the world
Hath long oppressed me.

sp.speaker: Ab
sp.l: But not pressed you right:
Now shall you bear a burden far more light.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What burden bearing? whereto tends this talk?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: To you, to us, this Abbey and King Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O God forfend he should be thought upon.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Lady make short, the King must lie with you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: With me, with me?

div.stage: First turns to the Monke, then to the Abbesse.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Sweet never look so strange:
He shall come closely, nobody shall see.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: How can he come, but one hath eyes to see?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Your chamber windows shall be shadowed.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But no vail from my conscience shadows me.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: And all the Nuns sent quietly to bed.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Quickly give guess of my lost maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: She goes i'faith, by God she is their own.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Be not so nice, the sin is venial:
Considering you yield for charity,
And by your fall, the Nunnery shall rise.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Regard good counsel daughter, pray be wise.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Come, here is a stir: wilt do wench? will it do?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Say Aye, say Aye, forget the sound of no:
Or else say no and take it: wilt thou so?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Do you intend thus lewdly as you speak?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Aye by gogs blood do they: and moppet, you were best
To take their proffers, lest if they forsake you,
I play the devils part, step in and take you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Some holy water, help me blessed Nuns.
Two damned spirits, in religious weeds,
Attempt to tempt my spotless chastity:
And a third devil gaping for my soul,
With horrid starings, ghastly frighteth me.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: You may call while you will: but maid list what we say,
Or be assured this is your dying day.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: In his name that did suffer for my sin,
And by this blessed sign, I conjure you:
Depart foul fiends, return from whence ye came:
Avoid ye fiends, and cease to trouble me.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: 'Swounds, she thinks us devils. Hear you conjurer?
Except you use that trick, to conjure down
The standing spirit of my Lord the King,
That your good mother there, the Abbess uses,
To conjure down the spirit of the Monk,
Not all your crosses have the power to bless
Your body from a sharpe and speedy death.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Are ye not fiends, but mortal bodies then?

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Maid, maid: catch lower, when you feele young men.
'Sblood, I was never taken for the devil till now?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O where shall chastity have true defence,
When Churchmen lay this siege to innocence?
Where shall a maid have certain sanctuary,
When Lady Lust rules all the Nunnery?
Now fie upon ye both, false seeming Saints,
Incarnate devils, devilish hypocrites.
A cowled Monk, an aged vailed Nun,
Become base Panders! and with lustful speech,
Assay the chaste ears of true maidenhead!
Now fie upon this age, would I were dead.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: Come leave her Lady; she shall have her wish.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Speed her I pray thee; should the baggage live,
She will slander all the chaste Nuns in the Land.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Well, well, go get you two unto your conjuring:
Let me alone to lay her on gods ground.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why dost thou stay?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Why maid, because I must:
I have a message to you from the king.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And thou art welcome to his humble maid.
I thought thee to be grim and fierce at first:
But now thou hast a sweet aspect, mild looks.
Art thou not come to kill me from the king?

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And thou art welcome, even the welcomest man,
That ever came unto a woeful maid.
Be brief good fellow: I have in the world,
No goods to give, no will at all to make:
But Gods will and the kings on me be done.
A little money kept to give in alms,
I have about me, deaths-man take it all:
Thou art the last poor alms-man I shall see.
Come, come, dispatch: what weapon will death wear,
When he assails me? Is it knife, or sword?
A strangling cord, or sudden flaming fire?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Neither, thou manly maid: look here, look here:
A cup of poison. Wherefore dost thou smile?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O God, in this the king is merciful.
My dear loved Huntington by poison died.
Good fellow, tell the king I thank his Grace,
And do forgive his causeless cruelty.
I do forgive thee too; but do advise
Thou leave this bloody course, and seek to save
Thy soul immortal, closed in thy breast:
Be brief I pray thee: now to King Iohns health
A full carouse; and god remember not
The curse he gave himself at Robins death,
Wishing by poison he might end his life,
If ever he solicited my love.
Farewell good fellow, now thy medicine works,
And with the labour, I am forced to rest.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: 'Swounds she cares not, she makes death a jest.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: The guiltless fear not death. Farewell good fried:
I pray thee be no trouble in my end.

div.stage:
He stands staring and quaking.
Enter Oxford, Queene, Abbesse, attendants.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: And say you Lady Abbess that there came
One from the King unto her? what was he?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Yonder he stands, I know not what he is.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Iesus have mercy. Oxford, come not nigh him.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Not nigh him Madam? yes: keep you away.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Come in good Queen: I do not mean to stay.
Nor I to stir, before I see the end.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Why starest thou thus? speak fellow, answer me.
Who art thou?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A bloody villain, and a murderer.
A hundred have I slain with mine own hands.
It was I that starved the Lady Bruse to death,
And her young son, at Windsor Castle late.
It is I have slain Matilda, blessed maid,
And now will hurry to damnations mouth,
Forced by the gnawing worm of conscience.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Hold him for gods sake: stay the desperate wretch.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O some good pitying man compassionate
That wretched man, so woeful desperate:
Save him for gods sake: he hath set me free,
From much worlds woe, much wrong, much misery.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I hear thy tongue, true perfect charity.
Chaste maid, fair maid, look up and speak to me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Who is here? my gracious sovereign Isabell?
I will take strength and kneel.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Matilda sit, I will kneel to thee. Forgive me, gentle girl,
My most ungentle wrongs.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Fair beauteous Queen,
I give god thanks, I do not think on wrongs.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: How now Fitzwaters child? how dost thou girl?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Well, my good Lord of Oxford: pretty well:
A little travel more, and I shall rest:
For I am almost at my journey's end.
O that my head were raised a little up:
My drowsy head, whose dim decaying lights,
Assure me it is almost time to sleep.
I thank your Highness, I have now some ease.
Be witness, I beseech your Majesty,
That I forgive the King, with all my heart:
With all the little of my living heart,
That gives me leave to say, I can forgive:
And I beseech high heaven he long may live
A happy King, a king beloved and feared.
Oxford, for gods sake, to my father write
The latest commendations of his child:
And say, Matilda kept his Honours charge,
Dying a spotless maiden undefiled.
Bid him be glad, for I am gone to joy:
I that did turn his weal to bitter woe.
The king and he will quickly now grow friends,
And by their friendship much content will grow.
Sink earth to earth, fade flower, ordained to fade:
But pass forth soul unto the shrine of peace,
Beg there atonement may be quickly made.
Fair Queen, kind Oxford, all good you attend:
Fly forth my soul, heavens king be there thy friend.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: O pity, mourning sight, age pitiless:
Are these the messages king Iohn doth send!
Keep in, my tears, for shame, your conduits keep,
Sad woe beholding eyes: no, will ye not?
Why, then in Gods name weep.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I cannot weep for wrath: here, here, take in
The blessed body of this noble maid:
In milk white clothing let the same be laid,
Upon an open bier, that all may see
King Iohns unkingly lust and cruelty.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Aye, be it so. Yourself, if so you please,
Will I attend upon, and both us wait
On chaste Matildaes body: which with speed,
To Windsor Castle we will hence convey:
There is another spectacle of ruth,
Old Bruses famished Lady and her son.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: There is the king besieging of young Bruse,
His Lords are there: who when they see this sight,
I know will have small heart for Iohn to fight.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: But where is the murderer, ha? is not he staid?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Borne with a violent rage, he climbed a tree,
And none of us could hinder his intent:
But getting to the top boughs, fast he tied
His garters to his neck, and a weak branch,
Which being unable to sustain his weight,
Down to the ground he fell, where bones and flesh
Lie pashed together, in a poole of blood.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Alas for woe; but this is just heavens doom
On those that live by blood: in blood they die.
May an example of it, honest friends,
Do well, take pains, beware of cruelty.
Come Madam, come, to Windsor let us go:
And there to Bruses grief, add greater woe.

div.stage: Exeunt. Enter Bruse, vpon the walles.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Will not my bitter bannings and sad plaints,
My just and execrable execrations,
My tears, my prayers, my pity-moving moans
Prevail, thou glorious bright Lamp of the day,
To cause thee keep an obit for their souls,
And dwell one month with the Antipodes?
Bright sun retire, gild not this vault of death,
With thy illustrate rays: retire, retire,
And yield black night thy Empery a while:
A little while, till as my tears be spent,
My blood be likewise shed in raining drops,
By the tempestuous rage of tyrant Iohn.
Learn of thy love, the morning: she hath wept,
Shower upon shower, of silver dewy tears.
High trees, low plants, and pretty little flowers
Witness her woe: on them her grief appears:
And as she droops on them, they do not let,
By drop and drop, their mother earth to wet.
See these hard stones, how fast small rivulets
Issue from them, though they seem issueless:
And wet eyed woe on everything is viewed:
Save in thy face that smilest at my distress.
O do not drink their tears thus greedily:
Yet let the mornings mourning garment dwell
Upon the sad earth. Wilt thou not, thou churl?
Then surfeit with thy exhalations speedily:
For all earths venomous infecting worms
Have belched their several poisons on the fields,
Mixing their simples in thy compound draught.
Well Phoebus well, drink on I say, drink on:
But when thou dost ungorge thee, grant me this,
Thou power those poisons on the head of Iohn.

div.stage: Drum. Enter Chester, Mowbray, Souldiers: Lester, Richmond at an other: Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: How now my Lords: were ye last night so pleased
With the beholding of that property,
Which Iohn and other murderers have wrought,
Upon my starved mother and her son:
That you are come again? Shall I again
Set open shop, show my dead ware, dear bought,
Of a relentless merchant that doth trade
On the red sea, swollen mighty with the blood
Of noble, virtuous, harmless innocents?
Whose cole black vessel is of Ebony,
Their shrouds and tackle (wrought and woven by wrong)
Stretched with no other gale of wind, but grief:
Whose sighs with full blasts beateth on her shrouds:
The Master murder is, the Pilot shame,
The Mariners rape, theft, and perjury:
The burden, tyrannous oppression,
Which hourly he in England doth unlade:
Say, shall I open shop, and show my wares?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: No, good Lord Bruse, we have enough of that.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: To Windsor welcome, Hubert: Soft: methinks
Bruse and our Lords are at a parley now?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Chester and Mowbray, you are Iohns sworn friends:
Will you see more? Speak, answer me my Lords:
I am no niggard, you shall have your fill.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We have too much, and surfeit with the woe.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Are you all full? Here comes a ravening kite,
That both at quick, at dead, at all will smite.
He shall, he must, I, and byrlady, may
Command me to give over holy day,
And set wide open, what you would not see.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Why stand ye Lords, and see this traitor perched,
Upon our Castles battlements so proud?
Come down young Bruse, set ope the castle gates:
Unto thy sovereign, let thy knee be bowed,
And mercy shall be given to thee and thine.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: O miserable thing:
Comes mercy from the mouth of Iohn our king?
Why then belike hell will be pitiful.
I will not ope the gates, the gate I will:
The gate where thy shame, and my sorrow sits.
See my dead mother, and her famished son:
Open thy tyrants eyes: for to the world,
I will lay open thy fell cruelties.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: We heard indeed, thy mother and her son
In prison died, by wilful famishment.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Sin doubled upon sin. Slanderest thou the dead?
Unwilling willingness it shall appear,
By then I have produced, as I will do,
The just presumptions against your unjust act.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Assail the castle Lords: Alarum drums:
And drown this screech-owls cries with your deep sounds.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: I tell thee drummer, if thy drum thou smite,
By heaven, I will send thy soul to hells dark night.
Hence with thy drum: gods passion, get thee hence:
Be gone I say, move not my patience.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Are you advised Lester, what you do?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: I am advised: for my Sovereign know,
There is not a Lord here will lift up his arm,
Against the person of yon noble youth,
Till you have heard the circumstantial truth,
By good presumptions, touching this foul deed.
Therefore go on young Bruse, proceed, retell
The allegation that puts in this doubt,
Whether thy mother through her wilfulness,
Famished herself and her sweet son, or no?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Unlikely supposition: nature first denies,
That any mother, when her youngling cries,
If she have means, is so unnatural
To let it faint and starve. But we will prove
She had no means; except this moanful mean,
This torture of herself. Come forth, come forth,
Sir William Blunt whom slander says I slew:
Come tell the king and Lords what you know true.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou hast betrayed our Castle.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: No: God can tell it was surprised by politic report,
And affirmation that your Grace was slain.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Go on, sir William Blunt:
Pass briefly to the Ladies famishment.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: About some ten days since, there came one Brand,
Bringing a signet from my Lord the king,
And this commission signed with his hand,
sp.stage: Lords looke, and reade the thing.
sp.l: Commanding me (as the contents express)
That I should presently deliver up
The Lady Bruse and her young son to him.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: What time a day was this?

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: It was, Lord Mowbray, somewhat past eleven:
For we were even then sitting down to dine.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: But did ye dine?

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: The Lady and her son did not:
Brand would not stay.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: No Lester, no: for here is no such sign
Of any meats digesture.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: But by the way. Tell us I pray you Blunt,
While she remained with you, was she distraught
With grief, or any other passions violent?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: She now and then would weep, and often pray,
For reconcilement twixt the king and Lords.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: How to her son did she affected stand?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Affection could not any more affect:
Nor might a mother show more mothers love.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.l: How to my Lord the king?

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: O my Lord God! I never knew a subject love king more:
She never would blin telling how his Grace
Saved her young son from soldiers, and from fire:
How fair he spake, gave her her son to keep:
And then, poor Lady, she would kiss her boy,
Pray for the king so hearty earnestly,
That in pure zeal, she wept most bitterly.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I weep for her, and do by heaven protest,
I honoured Bruses wife. How ever that slave
Rudely effected what I rashly willed:
Yet when he came again, and I bethought,
What bitter penance I had put them to,
For my conceived displeasure against old Bruse ,
I bad the villain post and bear them meat:
Which he excused, protesting pity moved him
To leave wine, bread, and other powdered meat,
More than they twain could in a fortnight eat.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Indeed, this can I witness with the king,
Which argues in that point his innocence:
Brand did bear in a months provision;
But locked it like a villain, far from them:
And locked them in a place where no man's ear
Might hear their lamentable woeful moans:
For all the issue both of vent and light,
Came from a loover at the towers top,
Till now Lord Bruse made open this wide gap.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Had I not reason, think you, to make wide
The window that should let so much woe forth?
Where sits my mother martyred by herself,
Hoping to save her child from martyrdom:
Where stands my brother martyred by himself,
Because he would not taste his mothers blood.
For thus I gather this: my mothers teeth and chin
Are bloody with the savage cookery,
Which her soft heart, through pity of her son,
Respectless, made her practise on herself:
And her right hand, with offering it the child,
Is with her own pure blood stained and defiled.
My little brothers lips and chin, alone,
Are tainted with the blood: but his even teeth,
Like orient pearl, or snow-white ivory,
Have not one touch of blood, one little spot:
Which is an argument the boy would not
Once stir his lips, to taste that bloody food,
Our cruel gentle mother ministered:
But as it seemed (for see, his pretty
Palm is bloody too) he cast it on the ground:
For on this side these blessed relics lie,
By famines rage divided from this shrine.
Sad woeful mother in Ierusalem,
Who when thy son and thou didst faint for food,
Buried his sweet flesh in thy hungry womb:
How merciless wert thou, if we compare
Thy fact and this? For my poor Lady mother
Did kill herself, to save my dying brother.
And thou ungentle son of Miriam,
Why didst thou beg life when thy mother lacked?
My little brother George did nobly act
A more courageous part; he would not eat,
Nor beg to live, it seemed he did not cry:
Few tears stand on his cheek, smooth is each eye:
But when he saw my mother bent to die,
He died with her: O childish valiancy!

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Good Bruse have done: my heart can not contain
The grief it holds, my eyes must shower down rain.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Which showers are even as good,
As rain in harvest, or a swelling flood
When neighbouring meadows lack the mowers sith.

div.stage: A march for buriall, with drum and fife. Enter Oxford, Matilda borne with Nuns, one carrying a white pendant. These words writ in golde; Amoris, Castitatis, & Honoris honos. The Queene following the Biere, carrying a Garland of flowers: set it in the midst of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: List Lester, hearst thou not a mournful march?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Yes Richmond, and it seemeth old de Vere.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Lords, by your leave, is not our sovereign here?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Yes good old Awbury.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Ah my gracious Lord,
That you so much your high state should neglect!
Ah god in heaven forgive this bloody deed.
Young Bruse, young Bruse, I weep,
Thy mothers and thy brothers wrong.
Yet to afflict thee more, more grief I bring.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: O Honourable Awbery de Vere,
Let sorrow in a sable suit appear:
Do not misshape her garments, like delight.
If it be grief, why clothest thou her in white?

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: I cannot tell thee yet: I must sit down.
Attend young Bruse, and listen to the Queen:
She will not be tongue tied, we shall have a stir
Anon, I fear, would make a man half sick.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Are you here lecher? O intemperate king,
Wilt thou not see me? come, come, show your face:
Your Graces graceless, kings, unkingly face.
What? mute, hands folded, eyes fixed on the earth?
Whose turn is next now to be murdered?
The famished Bruses are on yonder side:
On this another, I will name anon:
One for whose head this garland I do bear,
And this fair milk-white spotless pendant too.
Look up king Iohn, see, yonder sits thy shame:
Yonder it lies: what, must I tell her name?
It is Matilda, poisoned by thee.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Matilda: O that foul swift footed slave,
That kills ere one have time to bid him save.
Fair gentle girl, ungently made away.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: My banished uncles daughter, art thou there?
Then I defy all hope, and swear

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Stay Bruse, and listen well what oath to swear.
Lewys the Dolphin, pitying our estate,
Is by the Christian king his father, sent
With aid to help us, and is landed too.
Lords that will fly the den of cruelty,
And fight to free yourselves from tyranny,
Bruse, keep that Castle, to the only use
Of our elected king, Lewys of Fraunce.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Gods passion do not so: king Iohn is here.
Lords, whisper not with Lester. Lester, fie:
Stir not again regardless mutiny:
Speak to them Hugh: I know thou lovest the king.
Madam, go to them, nay do, for gods sake do:
Down with your stomach: for if he go down,
You must down too, and be no longer Queen:
Advise you, go entreat them speedily.
My sovereign, wherefore sit you sighing there?
The Lords are all about to follow Lewys:
Up and entreat them, else they will away.

sp.speaker: K,
sp.l: Good Oxford let them go. Why should they stay?

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: What? are you desperate? that must not be.
Hear me my Lords.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: This pendant let me see.
Amoris, Castitatis, and Honoris honos.
She was indeed of London the honour once,
When she was loved of virtuous Huntington :
Of chastity the honour, all her life:
To impure thoughts she never could be won.
And she of Honour was the honour too,
By birth, in life, she honour honoured.
Bring in two tapers lighted, quick, dispatch.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Remember Bruse, thy charge. Come Lords away.
Away, we will away.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Hark Lester but one word, a little stay.
Help me good Hubert, help me gentle Queen.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How dim these Tapers burn! they give no light.
Here were two beauteous Lamps, that could have taught
The Sun to shine by day, the Moon by night:
But they are dim too: clean extinguished.
Away with these, sith those fair lights be dead.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: And as I say, hark Bruse unto our talk.
Think you it is for love of England, Lewis comes?
Nay: Fraunce is not so kind: I would it were.
Advise yourselves; hark, dost thou hear me Bruse?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Oxford, I do.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Can noble English hearts bear the French yoke?
No Lester: Richmond think on Lewys sire,
That left you, and your king, in Palestine.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: And think beside, you know not Lewys nature,
Who may be as bad as Iohn, or rather worse than he.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: And look my Lords upon his silent woe:
His soul is at the door of death I know.
See how he seeks to suck, if he could draw,
Poison from dead Matildaes ashy lips.
I will be sworn his very heart strings nips.
A vengeance on that slave, that cursed Brand,
I will kill him if I live, with this right hand.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: Thou canst not Hubert, he hath killed himself:
But to our matter. Lester, pray thee speak.
Young Bruse, for gods sake let us know thy mind.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I would be loath to be a strangers slave:
For Englands love, I would no French king have.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Well Oxford, if I be deceived in Iohn again,
Its long of you, Lord Hubert, and the Queen.
Yield up the Castle Bruse, we will once more try
King Iohns proceedings. Oxford, tell him so.

div.stage: Oxford goes to the king, does his duety, and talkes with him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: I will come down: but first farewell dear mother.
Farewell poor little George, my pretty brother.
Now will I shut my shambles in again.
Farewell, farewell.
In everlasting bliss your sweet souls dwell.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: But you must mend i'faith, in faith you must.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: My Lord, once more your subjects do submit,
Beseeching you to think how things have past,
And let some comfort shine on us your friends,
Through the bright splendour of your virtuous life.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I thank you all; and Lester I protest,
I will be better than I yet have been.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Of Windsor Castle here the keys I yield.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thanks Bruse: forgive me, and I pray thee see
Thy mother and thy brother buried,
In Windsor Castle Church. Do, kiss her cheek:
Weep thou on that, on this side I will weep.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Chaste virgin, thus I crown thee with these flowers.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Let us go on to Dunmow with this maid:
Among the hallowed Nuns let her be laid:
Unto her tomb, a monthly pilgrimage
Doth king Iohn vow in penance for this wrong.
Go forward maids: on with Matildaes hearse,
And on her Tomb see you engrave this verse;
Within this Marble monument, doth lie
Matilda martyred, for her chastity.
Thus is Matildaes story shown in act,
And rough hewn out by an uncunning hand:
Being of the most material points compact,
That with the certainest state of truth do stand.
